description:
4-5.

Had dinner with my cousin, his girl, and my partner the other week.

It was pretty good: my soupy shanghai dumplings didn't have a lot of soup for some reasons or at least for the ones I ate except for two pieces. 

And the spicy pork/chives dumplings were pretty bomb. 

And the sweet and sour soup was pretty good.
author: Lilian L.

description:
We ordered the spicy wontons - which were so good! Would definitely double down on those next time.

Green beans were really good as well. XLB and pan fried pork buns were just ok.
author: Katherine K.

description:
Food arrived quickly. Under five minutes. Fried rice and lo mein were good tasting   but portions were smaller than at other local Chinese restaurants. Seems like a lot of money was paid for a meal which did not  fill the three of us.

Dumplings were very good. Best part of the meal. Wonton soup with dumplings was good but not as good as I remember it was at their other location, which is now closed. 

This restaurant was not busy at all. At noon on a weekday, it was about 15% full.

Waiter was pleasant and bathroom was satisfactorily clean.
author: Steven G.

description:
Seriously, their dumplings melted in your mouth without any texture or flavor.  The skin disintegrated while you transferred from steamer to your mouth.  Pork filling has strange "sweet" aftertaste, if that appeals to your sweet tooth.  Cold dishes like spicy beef stomach was salty, salty and salty!  
And the owner was having a great time swatting flies using his new electric fly swatter while we ate, seriously???
author: Foodie C.

description:
We had a meal catered by Shanghai Dumpling King.

It was super no bueno. The food was very oily and flavorless -- even soy and chili sauce did little to help it.

The best and only edible part of the meal was the rice. Yes - steamed white rice. My 2 star rating probably needs no further explanation after that, but that wouldn't be very yelpy of me.

There were several entrees and sides (see photos), and I tried the stir fried chicken and tofu, plus the Shanghai soup dumplings. Both the chicken and tofu just tasted like textured blobs of cooking oil....not actual meat or tofu. Ick :-( and the dumplings...well, I'm not quite sure what was in them, but there was certainly no broth (as per the sign) and the "pork" was rather interesting, too; it resembled (and unfortunately tasted like) dog food.
author: Nic Z.

description: Came to this location after other location closed on Balboa. Parking is pretty bad near this restaurant. This location is noisy because of the low ceilings, the other location had real high ceilings so the sound didn't seem as bad. Okay here's the good and not so good's, this restaurant still has XLB on the menu but the number is less, the skin is still pretty good but the stuffing is different, it does not seem to have as much vegetables in the mixture. The vinegar is different, the vinegar they use is a milder vinegar and it's a little sweeter. We also ordered the won ton soup, it's rather generic with no greens or vegetables in it. Also ordered was the pea shoots. It's woked with garlic and the nice thing about this dish is they did not add a lot of salt so you can season it to your own liking. I will be back, but I will bring my own vinegar. Great place if you have a urge for XLB.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Shanghai Dumpling King has never been the best Shanghai food I've had but it's always been good enough in a pinch. But this time, it was just abysmal and that was pretty sad to see.

We began our meal with the green onion pancake. Instead of being multi-layered with just a bit of elasticity in the bite, it was as crisp as a cracker and dry. It also had a really weird aftertaste. It's never a good sign when you crave green onion pancakes from the frozen aisle over this version. Next up was the dumplings in seafood soup. This was actually pretty decent - shrimp, calamari, bamboo shoots, shitake mushrooms and a fair number of dumplings made up this soup.

Next came the dan dan noodles which were an absolute travesty. The noodles were so thin and essentially weighted down by the sauce which didn't impart the delicious spicy/nutty flavors that you would expect. Overall, the dish was just gummy and not appealing. As for the stir-fried rice cakes, there wasn't enough oil in my opinion. The rice cakes suck together in towers. Also, instead of using napa, they used green cabbage which definitely made a difference as well.

Luckily, our last two dishes did provide a bit of redemption. The XLB was still good and the potstickers were also pretty decent in my opinion.

I almost feel like it'll have to be a pretty dire day before I choose to return any time soon.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
** 3.5 stars **
This place was better than I expected, which is actually saying something since I don't have really high expectations when it comes to this type of cuisine since there are very few places that meet my standards.  The atmosphere is a little dated, but the service was friendly.  The waiter gave us some helpful recommendations, but he wasn't pushy about them.  We ordered two dumpling dishes and green beans, both had good flavor, one of the dumpling dishes was a bit on the spicy side for me, but overall the dishes were good.  Prices were reasonable.
author: Andrea B.

description: The best thing about this place is the staff is friendly and the food is a bargain. I love the crispy rice soup here (guo ba). The dumplings are decent, not the best I've had. Good neighborhood spot.
author: Shaw L.

description:
We came here to grab a quick bite before heading off to the airport and back east. Although we wanted to go to our long-time favorite (Kingdom of Dumpling), it opened a little later and would have made it tough for us - so we decided to check out a new spot instead. We got here about 10 minutes after opening time on Sunday morning, and getting a seat was a cinch - there were maybe 5 other tables taken at most. The interior decor isn't anything to write home about, but at the least it doesn't feel as cramped as many a Chinese restaurant that might have a hole-in-the-wall feel to it do. Service was what I would expect - not too personable, but with quick delivery of food - so that was a-okay by me.

That said, even though this too is a restaurant that claims to be dumpling royalty, I was not as blown away by the Chinese food here as I have been elsewhere in SF. The soup dumplings, while sizable and having skin that holds together well, has broth that is a bit on the sweeter side, as well as pork that was a bit too soft to my liking. The skin was also on the thicker side, and there was less soup in the dumplings than I had expected. The lion's head meatballs - which were listed as a 'casserole' on the menu but came served in a giant pot that more closely-resembled soup - was a bit better, although it also had pork that almost had an undercooked texture to it (even though the flavor was fine). That said, I did enjoy the warmth of the broth, but there were too few noodles and a lot of filler (namely cabbage) floating around in it. The vermicelli noodles were probably the only dish that I enjoyed - it had a little bit of heat to it, and although it was vegetarian, it was nice and refreshing compared to much of the other items we had. The only other dumpling course we got were the spicy wontons, and I'm not quite sure what the preparation was based on...it had a heavily peanut-based sauce that made it taste more like Thai / South Asian, and the wonton skin was very thick (perhaps overcooked) relative to the vast majority of wontons (standalone, in soup, or otherwise) that I have had.

Everything here just kind of checks off the box, but when it came to execution, I didn't really think that this self-proclaimed dumpling king did the dumplings - or any of our other food - particularly well. I might go back to try out some other items (it's a big menu, and perhaps we didn't pick well), but given the large selection of Chinese restaurants in San Francisco, I would probably check out somewhere else first - or go back to Chinese restaurants I have been to that I know will be very good.
author: Asuka N.

description:
TDLR: Delicious dumplings (i recommend #4), dumplings cost $8-12 for eight, friendly service, parking might be hard

I was talking to a co-worker who goes to school in the San Francisco area and she recommended me this restaurant. When she told me about Shanghai Dumpling King, she was super excited and told me I have to go here. 

My boyfriend and I went this past weekend for an early anniversary date. We had trouble finding parking but eventually parked in a one-hour parking limit zone. We came around the time the restaurant opened for dinner time so we were able to get seated immediately and it was not packed.  

We ordered only dumplings:
(#4) Shanghai Steamed Dumpling - $7.95
(#5) Hung Zhou Crab and Pork Steamed Dumpling - $9.95
(#18) Spicy Chives and Shrimp Dumpling - $10.95

The Shanghai dumpling and the Hung Zhou dumpling are both soup dumplings. My boyfriend and I felt that the soup in the Shanghai dumpling was better than the other one (although both very delicious). The meat was very savoury. It was so good we decided to get another order of the Shanghai dumplings. 

The spicy shrimp dumpling was delicious as well. I'm not the type of person who can really handle spice, but these dumplings were at the perfect level for me. It wasn't too spicy where you focused more on the heat and getting water. The spice added just the right amount of kick and flavour to the dumplings. Plus, I am a huge fan of shrimp. If you prefer to have more spice, you can request that. 

The man who served us suggested us many things to help us make our choices when we were deciding what to order. When I went to the bathroom, I noticed someone vandalized the mirror to say "worst customer service" which made me kinda sad since the employees were friendly and were never an issue from my personal experience. 

I am surprised that the other location closed and that there aren't more positive reviews for this location. Although it is kind of pricey for dumplings, I definitely feel like it was worth it. On the car ride home, my boyfriend couldn't stop obsessing over the dumplings and was so happy that I took him there! In the future, I want to take a larger group so I can possibly get a larger variety and try different dumplings!
author: Shayla H.

description: Came back again for lunch on Saturday afternoon! :) This is like a hole in the wall. We ordered tons of food and enough for weekday left overs! They are about an hour away from home, so always gonna buy enough to make this long drive worth it! Two orders of spicy wontons, one order of pork and one order of crab xiao long bao, honey beef, and an order of combo fried rice. I was super impressed by the honey beef last time, but the beef was too dried this time. :( bummer! The spicy wontons and xiao long baos were good this time, so it was great! Still worth the drive! :D Thank you!
author: Michelle C.

description: I was reading some of the other reviews on this place and was hesitant on trying this place. It's ironic cause Im writing a review on how good this place is. I went and grabbed dinner here and was far from disappointed. We got the chicken chow mein, lemon chicken and the shrimp dumplings. The dumplings came out really freaking fast but tasted super fresh and stupendous. The chow mein was solid with their chili sauce. The chicken was HOT (in temperature), and was more chicken than breading, which is always a plus.
author: Navdeep D.

description: The spicy dumpling and shanghai crab with pork dumping are the must to try!  They r delicious. We traveled from OC to try this place since there were many good reviews on Instagram and it did not fail us.
author: BaoBao L.

description: The other dumplings are great, but the "Spicy pork rice dumpling"s were especially fantastic. It's like Tangyuan but salty+savory instead of sweet, or like Shanghainese Nian Gao but with meat filling. Thick chewy skin soaked in delicious sauce
author: Chang W.

description:
We don't really have chinese food this good down in the OC area, so it was a super good experience. My boyfriend and I came here on our first night at SF! We ordered the wonton soup, szechuan beef, fried rice, xlb, and stir-fried water-spinach w/ garlic. The food itself is super good! I had a blast eating all of them! The szechuan beef had a little kick to it, but it's nothing that I couldn't handle! The fried rice to me was pretty good, but I'm not into fried rice as much as my boyfriend is. The wonton soup and the xlb and the stir-fried veggies were really good! I have no complaints!

 The restaurant workers there were very friendly and made sure that we were greeted hello and goodbye! They often came by to ask if our meal was ok. While we were eating, one of the workers (a sweet asian woman) actually carried a table because there was not enough room to fit on our tiny table. 

Overall, I enjoyed the experience and I will make sure to come by again when I make another visit to SF!
author: Millie N.

description: Oh my god. All I can say is, YUUUUUM! This little hole in the wall is just so god damn delicious. They're specialty shanghai dumplings are to die for and they give you a big portion too! Well worth the money. You must also try their green beans, sweet and sour chicken, corn soup and chicken fried rice. I can't get enough of this place. Service is fast, food is piping hot, prices are decent. If you're looking for a good dining experience, this is definitely the place you're looking for.
author: Lupe R.

description: I'm currently on a soup dumpling journey and this spot has some of the best in the city!  Also necessary are the Dan Dan noodles, pea shoots, spicy dumplings, and the pan fried pork buns.
author: Jordan D.

description: If you're looking for an amazing soup dumpling, look no further: Shanghai Dumpling King has mastered the art. Apart from the infamous Soup Dumplings, the Spicy Chive Shrimp Dumpling is to die for: it's spicy and garlicky and you can taste the freshness of the shrimp with every bite. Even just writing this makes me want to eat Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Sydney G.

description: Who doesn't love XLB?! I came with a group of three other friends and we were in the neighborhood, craving XLB and rice cakes. We were seated immediately by the friendly servers. From my experience the food could have been better. The soup in the XLB was lacking, and if you know XLB, soup makes the dumpling amaaaazing. Not all dumplings had soup, so they def missed their mark last night. We ordered pork XLB and crab. I liked the crab a lot more than the pork, but the pork filled me up. The crab was more flavorful and filling than the pork. We also tried their spicy bacon rice cakes which was a special on the whiteboard. My friends and I were confused why they used bacon considering not a lot of chinese dishes include bacon... but we tried it anyway. The spice level was good and the dish was well seasoned, it was a little too salty for me though. I loved the green beans and thought it wasn't overly garlicky or salty :) I'd come back and give them another chance. For the price, its good food, and will get the job done if I am craving any XLB.
author: Debby N.

description:
I ordered delivery from here the last time, but figured the food would have tasted a lot better if we ate it in person, especially the xiao long baos. So we tried it again the other day. We ordered their spicy wontons, xlbs, and dan dan noodles. I really like their xiao long baos here with the vinegar/ginger dipping sauce. The skin looked a little thick, but it was actually not too bad. The xlbs were the only things I really enjoyed. The chili wontons were laying over mixture of a spicy sauce and peanut sauce or sesame sauce. I didn't really like how it tasted.. too peanut-y for me. I was hoping for something more spicy. The dan dan noodles were okay. They could've been a little more spicy as well.

It wasn't bad given that I would come here again to try other things on their menu!
author: Sydney C.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better." is right. The XLB, while it has a decent filling, is nonetheless just okay overall when compared to others (maybe not in this city, but outside of it, for sure). Not worth it for $1 each.

Inside the pan fried pork buns, it was 80% dough - what kind of bun is that!? Definitely not worth it for $1 each.

The string beans are good but they give you so few compared to most restaurants.

The stir fried noodles Shanghai style lacked flavor. It was like they forgot to add sauce, but clearly they had something on them.

It's no wonder the reviews recently have been so low.
author: Andrew R.

description: Love this restaurant! Best Shanghai dumplings ever. Egg puff pastries are amazing. Can't beat the prices. I recommend one order of soup dumplings per meat eater though.
author: Angela M.

description: We were happy to find a Shanghainese restaurant close by because we really needed a good dumpling fix and they held up to their rating. When we walked in, my husband was excited based on the mixed makeup of the people eating at 12:30 on a Saturday. There were Chinese families both speaking Cantonese and not, as well as non-Asians. The lack of decor, variety of simple tables, and Costco fold up chairs at some of the tables added to his excitement because he thought it meant they focused more on the food than how the place looked. He was right! The Spicy Won Ton was my favorite with the peanut sauce and hot oil. The Green Onion Pancake was really good dipped in the peanut sauce. The pancake wasn't too thick or thin and had a good semi flaky texture. It wasn't dense. Steve enjoyed the Shanghai Xiao Long Bao Dumplings with the soup inside and we both liked the Spicy Chives and Shrimp Dumplings. The spicy hot oil was tasty and the filling was very flavorful. We didn't care for their Hot & Sour Soup because it was too thin and lacked a certain something in the usual complex flavor of the soup but it didn't taste bad. They get 4 stars for food and service. We were immediately greeted when we stepped into the restaurant and they brought us water when asked which gets them extra stars as a Chinese restaurant. Our server entertained my husband's Cantonese so that's a plus. The women's restroom was also clean and well stocked and there was lots of street parking. We will be back to try other dishes. We were intrigued by the very good looking plate of Pea Sprouts and the pile of Shanghai Thick Noodles  this little girl said "mmmmmm" to.
author: Jen L.

description:
We came here for lunch on a Saturday and had:
- Cucumber salad (4/5) - Nicely flavored with garlic and salt.
- XLB (3/5) - Decent but a little on the (too) sweet side.
- Pan fried pork bun (1/5) - 95% oily dough, barely any meat.
- Beijing dumplings (2/5) - Boiled within an inch of its life, the wrapper was essentially disintegrating.
author: Simon L.

description: I don't know why the ratings here are so low.  I came up from SoCal (where there's Chinese food everywhere) and this has got to be one of the most authentic and amazing Chinese food I've ever had.  Not only were the food amazing, but the servers were also very kind.  They went out of their way to make sure we were comfortable and that we were enjoying our time there.  Definitely a go to spot if you're in the mood for some Chinese food along with funny and kind service!  Will be back the next time we come back up north!
author: Tony N.

description: Food was cold, no dipping sauce for calamari. Didn't eat it anyways because it was cold and rubbery. Food was not worth my money at all. Very disappointed I just spent money on this place. GO SOMEWHERE ELSE! Very rude delivery driver.
author: Jenn G.

description:
The Outer Mission location of Shanghai Dumpling King reminds me of the How I Met your Mother episode when Lily's apartment gets turned into a Chinese restaurant. The red carpeting, wooden chairs, and homey vibes make it look like it was once an apartment at some point. 

We only spent about $20 here, which was a serious steal:
+ XLB: The order of pork xiao long bao's comes in 10 dumplings and were bite sized, full of soup, and flavorful! 
+ SPICY WONTONS: There was not much spice in these wontons, but instead had plenty of garlic, scallions, and a peanut butter sauce! This is not what I expected of the dish, but I loved it so much! It was flavorful, savory, and nutty. 
We also ordered GREEN BEANS which were garlicky, salty, and a perfect vegetable to complement our meal!!
author: Sophie P.

description: Super good. Went here for dim sum. Affordable and easy. Would return
author: Lilly K.

description: Have not been back since last review but I saw a lot of customers eating so must see what the fuss is about.  Boo hoo, what a mistake, prices have went up but the food quality went South.  Ordered spicy wonton which was ok but sizes have shrunk.  Chicken noodles soup is msg loaded, and lack of flavor using cheap dry rice noodles from a bag.  Chow mein and fried rice is oily and half the portion of regular size.worse yet fried rice is rancid.  I'm guessing they are busy and use some old freeser reheat food that dated back to the Clinton years.  I'm mad and hungry, will not be back.
author: Mar H.

description: Cucumber salad was very crunchy with tons of fresh garlic & green onions. I am not sure what the flavor was but it was so tasty I wanted more!! The Moo Shoo Pork was great and the pancakes super thin.  The hot and sour soup was very spicy. I would have liked more ingredients in it, but still might good. We ordered takeout.
author: Terese C.

description:
I was a longtime fan of the Balboa Street location, but the place was a bit small, cash only, and lacked ambiance. I much prefer this location. It has the same amazing dumplings, but is bigger, takes cards, and is a bit cleaner.

We always get a feast when we come here, and leave stuffed. The xiao long bao are of course a big favorite. Pro tip: do NOT put the whole thing in your mouth at once. It's filled with scalding hot liquid. I warned two separate guests not to do this, and they both did it anyway and writhed in pain as their mouths melted off. Why will no one listen? Sigh.

The spicy wontons are my second favorite. They're not really that spicy, but they come in a peanut sauce that's unlike anything I've had before on a dumpling. The Shanghai style fried noodles are a must, as is their green bean dish. Everything I've had is amazing here.

The best part is that they have dim sum all day long, not just for brunch time.

Whoever he is, he really is the dumpling king.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
I first ordered from here through UberEats and was a fan of their dumplings and the price. My first time there for a sit-down experience, I noticed that one half of the restaurant had a long line for UberEats drivers to hang out and a stack of dumpling orders in to go boxes waiting to be delivered. Since they have partnered up with UberEats and Caviar, their website actually has a very nice menu layout where you can see the prices and pictures of each item. Much more useful in helping me determine what to order if I can see what it will look like.

My favorites are the spicy wontons. If you're getting their spicy wonton or their spicy dumplings, you don't need to dip it in any additional soy sauce or dipping sauce. Why? Because the dumplings are already SAUCY. They're so saucy that they're straight up sassing you in the face. 

SPICY WONTON
Extra saucy. A spicy sauce with a deep peanut sauce taste embedded. Wrapped in thin wonton skin. Could probably eat two orders of this.

SPICY CHIVES AND PORK DUMPLING
Wrapped in a thicker dumpling skin. Because of the thicker skin, it's kinda doughy and is not as flavorful compared to the wontons. Similar to spicy wonton but less saucy.

BEEF FILLET WITH HONEY SAUCE
Beef was tender and delicious with the sauce and veggies. Need a bowl of rice to go with it.
author: Diana C.

description: We had the pea shoot sautéed with garlic, spicy wonton, xiao long bao and the shrimp/chives dumpling. It was pretty decent though the peanut sauce in the spicy wonton was strange. Service was prompt, dumplings were juicy- I have had better but pretty good for a neighborhood joint.
author: K C.

description: Ordered takeouts from this place, we ordered: Chicken Stir Fry, Tofu Stir, Dry Fried Garlic String Beans, Shanghai Soup Dumplings(xiaolongbaos), Spicy Chive & Shrimp Dumplings and Steamed Vegetable Dumplings. I was honestly impressed with their XLB, I was not expecting the XLBs to have any soups left by the time the delivery make it to the office, I was wrong. Their string beans was ok, their chive & shrimp dumping was acceptable. I think giving their food 3-star is extremely fitting. Everything was mediocre.
author: Jie L.

description: This was probably and is my favorite and the best (Chinese) restaurant that my parents and I have been to here in California during our 1 week vacation stay in San Francisco! We went for here for the very first time on Wednesday August 16th for dinner and of course ever since then yesterday and today we went there again for the 2nd and 3rd times! Overall it's our first trip to the West Coast and first time going to California as a whole so I guess we took full advantage of it! In the simplistic of terms it's more about quality than quantity! I say this because when u order a specific dish they really don't give u that much but that's okay because it's better for them to give u a small amount than in one huge enormous dish when you would think that you won't be able to finish it! So what my family did when we went here we order 2 of those small dishes instead of 1 cuz we knew they wouldn't give us one big dish in case we couldn't finish it! So if you are reading this and want to know what it is like to eat at this place, just keep in mind that it's more about the taste, quality and how much u can eat and NOT about quantity ordering too much when u can't finish it!
author: Edward C.

description:
Ate here 5 years ago and just came back last week. The stars don't lie, and my verdict is still the same as before. I ordered 5 dishes each time and distinctly remember the only good thing that I ordered was the peanut sauce wontons. 5 stars for that. Everything else was 3 or below.

Soup dumplings were completely miss. They were empty with no soup. Sent them back to the kitchen and waitress told me that they won't be able to make it with extra soup. Sad times when you can't live up to the name of your restaurant. One of the worst XLB places that I ever had.

I ordered bean sprouts, they were 2/5 stars, bland, no salt at all, and didn't seem fresh. My standard is San Tung. This dush is not even half as good.

Steamed dumplings. Hated them 5 years ago, still hate them to this date. Buns were doughy and meat was cooked burn small portion for babies. Sent them back into the kitchen to heat the buns and came out a little more burnt but still chewy texture. Very sad, don't bother ordering this dish unless you want half cooked baos.

Parents are with us and ordered sweet and sour pork and a honey glazed beef dish. Both were below average compared and even worse than panda express. How is that possible, the waiters and cashier/owner all seem to speak Cantonese fluently. This place is authentic, they should be able to flawlessly prepare these fundamental dishes.

I'm very disappointed, the 2 star review is because the peanut sauce wontons are that amazing. Even though it was slightly cold and not hot all the way, they were that good. If you don't really care about Chinese food or have lower standards, please go ahead and try this place, but don't say I didn't warn you.
author: Gordon Z.

description:
Ever since my original experience on which I based my original review, I have dined at Shanghai dumpling several times and each of those times, knowing the better items to order, I have been very satisfied with the food. The service is always friendly and unless they're hosting some sort of huge event, it can be pretty fast to get a table. The stand out items are the shanghai style Stirfried noodles, the chicken fried rice, the XLB, the spicy wontons, and the garlic pea shoots.  It's really hard to find a dish that doesn't just knock your socks off. All of the dumplings are great and their noodles are really good too. 

I've only ever had one dish there that was bad and that was the Dan Dan noodles. I ordered them a long time ago and forgot how much I didn't like them and then made the mistake of ordering them again tonight. In an effort to try to be tactful in my description let's just say that if you Google what Dan Dan noodles look like and see the minced meat topping that comes over the noodles and imagine if you were dining with a child, what the child might say that topping looks like... Do you get my drift? Well let's just say that it smells like that too...the noodles also have a strange smell and an unappealing texture and flavor. The stir fried rice cakes were also kind of a fail, it was too much rice cake and not enough of anything else (sauce, mix-ins)
author: Emma H.

description:
Super easy to grab a table here. We got xiao long bao, potstickers, shanghai-style stir fried noodles, braised tofu & mushrooms, fried chicken. About $44 total.

Taste wise, it was mediocre - the braised tofu & mushrooms sauce tasted super thick as if there was something added to it (perhaps corn starch?), xiao long bao was juicy, potstickers were your typical guilty pleasure fatty fried tasting yumminess - but took forever for us to get them. It actually came out last when we ordered it as an appetizer.

Service was a bit slow, but they had A TON of take-out and delivery orders, so it almost seemed like the dine-in people were working with an understaffed situation.
author: Cheri C.

description:
This is my second time here, first time here (a year ago), everything was fine, got seated, got our orders right, food is good, service is okay, no complaints, but lots of Caucasian customers (probably locals that live close by) 
Decided to come here instead of kingdom of dumplings because it was closer by my friends house
But tonight ... they ripped us off 
Came in, waited 3 mins to seated because none of the tables were cleaned, service seemed fast for a regular night (not busy not slow)
My friend, her little sister and I ordered 4 dishes- garlic broccoli, Shanghai style meat wonton soup (10 pieces), hung zhou crab & pork dumplings (8) & vegetable/pork dumplings (8)
Simple right, but we were missing 2 dumplings from the soup ... 
I don't know if it's because it's 3 girls and they think we won't be eating a lot or finish or did they change their menu but didn't update the actual menu...? 
Either or.. I don't think it's right to not give us our 10 pieces 
2 pieces is $2 I just lost if I were to just purchase a 3 pieces plate 
I won't be returning
author: Fiona B.

description: great place for dumplings, wait can be long at times. bummed that it appears they no longer deliver, otherwise this would be my go to place when i dont feel like dragging my butt off the couch.
author: Long C.

description:
Really friendly staff, food was quick & hot made to order!!! Had a really nice server who served my friend & I, he also gave us great recommendations on the menu! 

Parking a bit tough, so I would definitely try to take some sort of public transportation if you could!

Great place for dumplings for sure!!
author: Rj L.

description:
Here is an extremely honest review. I hate to have to give these guys 2 stars but this is why I am.

The prices are overinflated to an unacceptable level. $10 for pea shoots, which are good, but a smallish portion, is not cool. They are delicious, but that only goes so far. 

$10 for "special shrimp chive dumplings". Once again, this is not ok. They're tasty, but the ones at Dragon Beaux (a 5-star dim sum experience) are much better, and, unbelievably, cheaper. WAY overpriced here for a handful of dumplings made from Restaurant Depot ingredients.

But here's the real kicker, and it's tempting to give an honest 1-star review for this- the hot and sour soup. I've eaten at this place at least half a dozen times because of convenience and the tasty aforementioned pea shoots and shrimp dumplings (despite the unfairly high prices of those items) and I've never had better than a semi-decent hot and sour soup. But today's soup is so insultingly unacceptable it actually hurts my feelings.

It's obscenely vinegar-y and otherwise as flavorless as you could possibly make a soup. It doesn't just taste like, but rather IS A FACT that they just threw water, vinegar, soy sauce, salt, and canned bamboo shoots in a pot with some egg beaten in and a few chunks of tofu. It honestly tastes HORRIBLE, too horrible to eat. It's sour, bland, and probably the most disappointing thing I've ever gotten from a restaurant aside from something that's given me food poisoning. 

I just gave these guys $45 for a walk-in take-out order (because I tipped $4 to be nice) and got what amounts to two appetizers and a terrible soup. 

I'm changing the rating to one star honestly. This is so disappointing.  

The fact of the matter is nobody should ever serve a fake soup that's this shitty, and if you do, there's going to be consequences, which in this case is my honest, heavy-hearted 1-star review.
author: Grizzle J.

description:
this place has the best xlb/ soup dumplings i have ever eaten i don't care what anyone else says!!!!!!

the food is amazing, employees are really sweet and service is great. also this location takes credit card and the other one doesn't! and it's bigger/ not as crowded. i prefer this one.

xlb - 10/10!!!!!!
ok so they're not always really soupy and they sometimes fall apart .... but they taste soooo good lol

pan fried pork bao - 8/10

pea shoot - 10/10

string beans - 10/10

sticky rice dumpling - 10/10 !!!
highly recommend. this is my other favorite dish and i've never really eaten anything like it. the dumpling has a mochi like consistency and they taste way better at this location than the balboa one.
author: Christine G.

description: This place is one of my go to favorites and has very fast delivery (but I do live fairly close). My favorite dishes are Shanghai soup dumplings (XLB), pork over dry noodles (can't remember name).  Prices are reasonable.
author: Quincy Y.

description:
A solid 3.5 but rounded up to a 4, for convenience, since I live near this area and there aren't many (if any..?!) options for good dumplings within a 15 minute drive.

Not a destination spot for dumplings but definitely a solid option if you're in the 'hood! Sat in at 5:30 and there was a constant stream of customers, I think all regulars and people who live in the neighborhood! Always a good sign.

We ordered 4 things:

Garlic eggplant - big portion and not overfried, oversauced, or over-thickened with cornstarch! I dig it.

Lamb potstickers - filling was scant, but I really liked the skin on the potsticker (not too thin or thick) and it was perfectly fried otherwise. Just OK for me.

Spicy wontons - pretty tasting. I love the peanut/hot sauce mix! Not as good as my favorite option in the city but a very, very solid alternative for me, especially considering the closer proximity and shorter drive.

Beef stew claypot - Just OK. Big portion and lots of meat, but the tendon was pretty tough. If it was stewed for longer and it would have been better!

I'll definitely be a return customer and most likely a regular, since my fiance is a dumpling fiend!
author: Emily C.

description: No frills, but so good. This is the place that got me obsessed with dumplings. Their soup dumplings esp are delicious and the green onion pancake is phenomenal. The best part? The prices are very reasonable so you can get a good table full of food, eat to your heart's content and do so without breaking the bank. Recommend sharing family style so you get to try lots of things.
author: Maansi D.

description:
I do not like rushing to make food decisions because there's too much at stake. In the midst of deciding whether to go right or left, my friend put the pressure on me and I'm afraid I failed. We ended up here and while the food wasn't necessary inedible, it didn't quite hit the three star mark. 

Let's start with the Hangzhou pork and crab soup dumplings. Right when we sat down, they started giving us ginger and soy sauce so I was hyped for some dumplings already. They arrived steaming hot but when I looked inside, half the soup had already spilled out into the basket. The half I did get to eat was okay, although it had a good amount of filling. Up next was the spicy fish filet that really was more like fried orange fish filets. The dish wasn't spicy and has absolutely no peppers! We even asked if it was the right dish we ordered and the owner said yes. Lastly, got a vegetable dish and hot and sour soup. The soup didn't have any meat! So I counted that as two vegetable dishes for the day. That's supposed to be good for health and stuff right?

If you're a woman or girl, beware of the restroom. Some random man who apparently was good buddies with the staff/owners considers it gender neutral. That's even gross to me and I'm a guy.
author: Quoc N.

description:
I'm not Chinese so I can't speak to the authenticity but everything we had was delicious.

This was our second time here and it was as good as the first time! We had the green onion pancake (which our 4-year-old and 1-year-old devoured), the pot stickers, the spicy wontons, the fried tread bread, and the Shanghai dumplings. Each flavor different from the rest, all so tasty. A hit with our kids and us alike. The table next to us recommended the Shanghai noodles as well - next time!

Last time we came here with a larger group and it was such fun getting to try a huge variety of dishes.
author: Emily D.

description:
I only frequent this place because I live one block away... but I wish the food were better.

Assumed that having 'dumpling' and 'king' in the name would make for some delicious soup dumplings, but unfortunately, I was wrong. I've been to this location three times thus far (probably will go more just due to pure convenience), and each time, I have ordered their Shanghai Steamed Buns (AKA soup dumplings or XLB), and each time I have been disappointed - there is no soup to be found!! My roommate did tell me that she went one time and had soup in every one of her dumplings, but I'll believe it when I experience it myself. As of now, I have yet to try a true soup-filled dumpling at this place.

The other food on the menu is mediocre at best. Most tasty option is probably the pork potstickers. I've also ordered the pan fried buns and stir fried string beans, both of which could be greatly improved - pan fried buns needed more meat and less dough; string beans were just not spicy/authentically Szechuan at all.

Hopefully, I'll eventually have an experience here like my roommate with deliciously soupy dumplings...
author: Sheila D.

description: I love dumplings and so far this is my favorite place to get them. There are so many different options. This location is more out of the way than the Balboa location, but I prefer it since it's more spacious and accepts credit cards.
author: Lillian B.

description:
Going to start singing praises about this location for 3 reasons: 

1) WAY less crowded - Sunday morning at 11 AM, there's no line, even by noon the restaurants still half empty. If you're Uber-ing, you might as well come to this location 
2) they accept credit cards at this location!!! Because cash only can really screw you over when literally none of you or your friends carry cash ever.
3) the XLB Dumplings here are HELLA juicy. I mean they are at the other location but literally I got three trays and I'd say 25/30 were like squirting with soup when you bit into them- prob since there's less volume at this location. It's marvelous- chose not to include the picture of the soup squirting onto my jeans but you get the point.

Stuck with all my favorite things - XLB dumplings (#4 on the menu), pea shoot with garlic, green onion pancake - though green onion pancake was slightly less hot when it came out but otherwise great. 

Only thing is we ordered steamed pork buns - found them a bit underwhelming, decent flavor but not special in my opinion. 

Overall solid place especially this location!!
author: Kristie M.

description:
We come here at least twice a month and order the same thing every time: 3 - 4 orders of Shanghai dumplings. If you're looking for the precise thin skin / shape of Shanghai dumplings that you'd find at DTF, this is not the place. The soup dumplings here have a good amount of soup with a very tasty filling and a dough-ier wrapper than traditional xlb, which I love.

The interior is clean and the service is good. The lady who is always there is super nice and friendly.
author: Dani T.

description: Great little dumpling place. Service was efficient and prompt. Dumplings were tasty and filling. Perhaps they are not the finest examples of the genre, but to me this is more of a friendly filling meal with friends place, not fine dining. We got the pork soup dumplings and the crab equivalent. Finish with the sugar egg puff. For the price I was extremely satisfied.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Mmmm.... dumplings. SF is 90% of the time ideal weather for steamy dumpling comfort food, and Shanghai Dumpling King hits the spot. Although the restaurant is most well known for its XLB, I much preferred everything else.

(-) XLB ($7/10): Really dry and deflated... which is quite blasphemous for XLB which are supposed to be filled with broth.

(++) Hung Zhou Crab & Pork Dumplings ($10/8): The highlight of the meal! Could use more crab, but the blend was quite tasty and juicy.

(+/-) Beijing Style Boiled Chives Dumplings ($6.50/10): The skin is doughy and overwhelms the skimpy pork filling. I think House of Pancake and King of Doodle have better basic dumplings.

(++) Spicy Wonton ($6.50/10): Very different from the traditional Taiwanese spicy wonton I was expecting. It was hardly spicy at all, instead quite peanut butter-y, which actually turned out to pair well with the meaty wonton.

Overall, the dumplings were satisfying (good enough to have dumplings monotherapy for dinner!). The skins tended to be thick, and it's rather mediocre when you employ standard XLB/dumpling standards. However I do appreciate Shanghai Dumpling King for its home cooking style and associated idiosyncrasies, for better or for worse. I.e. you get interesting novelties like crab dumplings and wonton with peanut sauce, but also laughing stock matters such as dehydrated XLB and non-spicy spicy wonton.

Other notes:
*Ambiance is simple and cozy.
*Street parking only, not too difficult compared to the rest of SF.
*Location is a bit random in the Outer Mission.
*Service is efficient and the food came out quickly, though it seemed lukewarm (that, or I spent too much time taking food pictures :X)
author: Edna C.

description:
I would give 0 stars if I can. Now if someone ask me where is the worst Shanghainese/Chinese restaurant you know, it would definitely be this one. 

My girlfriend and I walked into Shanghai Dumpling King thinking that this place probably specializes Shanghainese food. As a Shanghainese, I ordered 4 very Shanghainese dishes, expecting them to nail it since I thought they specialize Shanghainese food. 

First up, Shanghai drunken Chicken as appetizer. This is probably the only edible dish i ordered, which I finished 1/3 of it. Although, the taste is definitely not genuine Shanghai drunken chicken, it's still edible.

Second, Soy-brazed lion head meatballs. Oh boy... I can write an essay on how bad this tasted. To keep things short, meatballs had no flavor, super blend. It doesn't even taste like fresh meat. Meat wasn't fully grind, I literally bit onto a chunk of fat. To make matters worst, the meatballs weren't even round in shape. I took two bites hoping that something was wrong with my tastebuds on the first bite. Can't even describe how much I regret the second bite, spitted out immediately.

Shanghai Vegetable delight. First of all, they got 50% of the ingredients right for this dish. The vinegar taste to this dish just threw my appetite. Traditional Shanghai vegetable delight is not suppose to have vinegar taste to it, but if you're going to add vinegar to it at least make it tasty and appetizing. That vinegar taste destroyed it.

Last up. The all famous shanghai Xiao long Bao. After the first 3 dishes, I was ready to get my check and leave. But seeing that every table had Xiao long Bao, I still had a slight of hope that Xiao long Bao could be the saving grace. Guess what? Not!!!!! Please please please don't say this is Shanghai Xiao long Bao. Shanghainese people love sweet taste of things, but dude Xiao long Bao is not suppose to be that sweet. That Xiao long Bao ruins the expectation of Shanghainese culture. I had freaking tears in my heart when I had Xiao long Bao taste like that.

All in all, my girl friend and I ate less than 1/4 of our food. We got the check and left in less than 15 minutes. Yes, it was that bad. We didn't even bother about the wasted food or money, we just wanted to make sure we didn't throw up. On the upside, the waiter took off the charge for lion head because I expressed how bad it tasted. Ironically, the waiter told me that they soy braised the lion head meatballs the whole day....So in my mind, I really wanted to ask if they are using fake soy sauce or what?

In summation, I rarely post things on yelp if any. But I had to do this because this restaurant literally just helped me understand a new level of bad Shanghainese/Chinese food. 

Some advice for owner. Please either take off the "Shanghainese" brand or fire your chef. Clearly, all the traditional shanghainese food I ordered tasted nothing like Shanghainese, so just call it a Chinese takeout if you specialize broccoli beef/chicken, general tso stuff.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
So it looks like I missed the lunch rush and special pricing for lunch too.

I ordered the snow pea shoots $10.95 with garlic, spicy wontons $6.99 and kung pao shrimp $9.99.  

DO not order the kung pao shrimp off the regular menu as it is loaded with tiny bay shrimp and fillers of onion, red and green bell peppers and canned, yes canned, mushrooms.  Yuck!

The snow pea shoots were plentiful and super tender.  Yes, I know that you can buy them at an  asian market for about $5 per bag, but by the time you clean them you've got almost nothing left.  So, yes, the $10.95 is the market price.

The best thing is the spicy wontons in a creamy sesame sauce - these are worth ordering another TO GO!

Service is your typical chinese I dont care about you so dont take it personal.
author: Charlie B.

description:
I used to live around here and it would be my go to restaurant when I couldn't decide what to eat. This is my favorite restaurant in the city to get XLB (xiao long bao)! I like how the skin is very thin although I wish there was more soup. 

Another favorite of mine is their Zha Jiang Mian (minced pork noodles). Make sure you mix the ingredients so each bite you make has the sauce, minced pork and noodles. I highly recommend this dish! For the portions you get, you can't beat the price especially in San Francisco.
author: Frances K.

description: Whenever I visit my childhood city, San Francisco, this is one of the restaurants that I always order from before heading home. This restaurant has the best spicy tendon and spicy wontons! Furthermore, they serve an abundance of different dumplings, including my favorite, Xiu Long Bao. I would highly recommend this restaurant when in San Francisco.
author: Ann H.

description: Great flavor. Inexpensive. Easy parking. I got the Shanghai dumplings and Mongolian beef lunch special. Total was $17. Would come back.
author: Alex C.

description: So when you order food online they don't actually make the food you order, despite getting a confirmation email stating that the order is being prepared. So when you drive half an hour out of your way to pick up your order, you find out they never started making it. Then they yell at you because they claim they called you 3 times, yet you don't have any missed calls on your phone.
author: Nat I.

description:
I said it before, and I'll say it again, I don't know jack about Asian food. And with so many experts in the field residing locally, I prefer to let them decide for me. But for my money, it doesn't get much better than Shanghai Dumpling King. 

I was having a terrible day before I arrived to SDK. I just had the worst flight ever home from Atlanta (sitting bitch on a 5 hour flight = never again). Some jackhole called me a bitch in the crosswalk for no reason. Then I couldn't find parking at or near SDK. In other words, my fuse was LIT. Once I found parking, I debated turning around and returning home, as I was already 0 for 3. It didn't seem like a good plan to test the universe when it was so clearly working against me that day. But I'm so glad I did not! SDK really turned the day around for me. 

We walked in and were sat and served on the quick, which is my favorite. I had a beer in hand in the blink of an eye, which is also my favorite. 

We looked at the menu and made some fast dumpling decisions. When our server arrived to take our order, we told her what we wanted and she made some great recommendations. We ordered the wontons (which are not really a wonton), Shanghai steamed dumplings, spicy Chive and shrimp dumplings, BBQ pork buns, and veggies with tofu. Our server rubber stamped all of those wonderful choices. We were going to get the pork and Chive dumplings as well, but thank goodness she talked us out of it. Friends, it was a lot of food for two people, and we ate ALL OF IT. It was all so deliciously filling. 

Our selections arrived to our table faster than immediately, which we were stoked about. I ate the majority of the BBQ Pork Buns. I love the texture of those things - it's like eating a little cloud with a yummy pork surprise inside. The wontons (which are not your traditional wontons) were served in an excellent peanut sauce. Our server said everyone loved them, and you can see why- very flavorful. The shrimp and spicy Chive dumplings were excellent, and I loved the texture. SDK's namesake, the Shanghai dumpling, likewise did not disappoint, even though I will cop to eating them incorrectly. I cut it them in half, which you aren't supposed to do since the broth will spill out of the dumpling. Whoops! My only complaint was that everything was so good, I couldn't stop eating even though the dumplings were hot as balls, temperature wise.  I burnt the roof of my mouth more than once. 

The prices are dirt for San Francisco. All of those delicious delectables and beers were $50 and change. At any other full service restaurant in this city, you would likely leave hungry. 

I was so enthused I ordered SDK for delivery last Sunday off of the OrderAhead app (less than a week after my first visit), and my order arrived quickly-still hot and delicious. 

The ambiance is unremarkable. You won't care. I know I didn't. The crowd was great and relaxed. You can definitely wear your yoga pants to SDK without incident. The buzz from the SF Weekly's review has maybe died down, although I hear the SDK on Balboa usually has a long wait. 

I recommend the chili sauce on the table. It is not as oily as most. 

The prices are very reasonable. The service is warm and friendly. The dumplings are delicious. What more could you want? Yet another reason to love Glen Park. Enjoy!!
author: Sunny S.

description:
Solid mid-tier Shanghainese spot!

It's so far out that it is easy to snag a table here. The inside is pretty drab, but appears clean at first glance (the bathrooms were clean - good sign).

The service is super rushed (expected all dishes to come at once) and a little direct. Most servers speak no English and the one or two that do ain't go no time for wishy-washy!

The food is fine, nothing amazing. Some good flavors/textures in some of the dumplings. The XLB was a hugeee miss although - 4/6 of them had no soup inside #Failll. 
Everything else was fine, just not super fantastic. 

Wish their food was spicier. Even the 'chili sauce' on the table tastes like its mostly garlic.
author: Nathan L.

description:
3.5 stars. Solid Chinese joint with fair prices.

This time I came in a group of 12 and service was excellent and friendly.

To order/recommendations
-XLB solid, you can't go wrong ordering these
-the server recommended we order this honey beef dish (after we ordered the honey walnut prawns) and i can't find it on the menu but it was really good and definitely would recommend trying this dish! It's a just the right amount of sweetness on the beef and it's served with bell peppers and onions

Wouldn't order again
-Twice cooked pork: meat was very tough and overall the dish wasn't very good
author: Mimi T.

description: This was my first time here but hands down some of my favorite dumplings I have ever had. Ordering these was an experience I won't forgot. For a solid price of 8 dumplings of $7.95 there was enough for me and my girlfriend to enjoy. The food is priced fairly and the taste is even better.
author: Jacob D.

description:
Great 2nd location!

Shanghai Dumpling King is now conveniently located off of 280, and lucky for me, just a few blocks away from my grandparents' house. This location has less of a hole in the wall feel than the Balboa restaurant, but in a good way. 

The interior is clean and spacious with ample seating. There is plenty of free and metered street parking around the restaurant. The staff is friendly and the food comes out super quick. 

We usually order the XLBs and pea sprouts, and have also tried the spicy chive and shrimp dumplings, spicy chicken wings, and chives and meat pastry. They offer a mango lassi, which is nice and refreshing on a warm day.

The food has consistently been delicious, and I don't mind frequenting this spot!
author: Camille B.

description:
Stop using MSG
Give people having a migrain headache and feeling sluggish after 

Stop using MSG
Give people having a migrain headache and feeling sluggish after 

Stop using MSG
Give people having a migrain headache and feeling sluggish after
author: Chef C.

description:
Beware - yelp says they close at 9:30 on the weekends, but it is 9 every night.  Also if you arrive after 8:30, they probably won't seat you so they REALLY close at 8:30.  

The food is good.  Standard order is Dan Dan Noodles (could be spicier), some type of dumpling - usually spicy wonton and the pea shoots.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
Very sad to be writing this review but it has to be done.

My family and I usually come here for dinner when there's a special occasion or for the too-lazy-to-cook nights.  After our last visit, I don't think I'd ever want to come back.

Not sure if it is a change of management or what, but they totally skimped out on their portions now. Their dishes are pretty small for their prices and the quality is just so general/nothing special.  I still can't believe there were only about 10 walnuts on a shrimp & walnut dish, c'mon man.  Also how can the restaurant be called "Dumpling King" when the XLB dumplings were super soggy and wet where all the soup that's supposed to be inside of the dumplings all spilled/leaked out. 

The service is pretty bad too.  We came here with a party of 7 and in an Asian restaurant, you'd think they'd actually serve the soup... but nope.  They placed the soup on the OPPOSITE end of the turning/serving table of where the bowls were set at.. then just left it there.  So my family and I awkwardly had to move the soup bowls closer to where the soup was then had to scoop it into the bowls ourselves.  Odd.  Only experienced that when it's like a party of 2 or 3.  Not a party of 7 though.  

The order of the food that came out was also very odd.  First was the vegetables... what? And my family and I let it sit there for a good 5 minutes until a meat dish came out to compliment the vegetables.. Am I missing something or is this a new style of serving food...

Ugh honestly I was so upset with everything that it pretty much ruined the vibe for me and my family's meal.  We ordered about 9-10 dishes and weren't even full off of it, what the hell.  So my dad even ordered an extra chow mein to make sure everyone had an efficient amount of food in the end.  Lame. 

I also noticed they seemed to have focused more on their to-go meals.  It also seems they are tailoring their dishes more to their non-Asian guests.  

I really hate writing bad reviews but this one was just so terrible.  Never going to return.
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
Came here with my mom and brother for lunch before we do our errands. 

Here are the things that we order:

we were suppose to get the shanghai soup dumpling, but when it came out, it was totally different which was the the shrimp dumpling. When we call the waiter who took our order about this dumpling. he misheard us and thought we wanted the shrimp instead and probably didnt understand us from the beginning even though we said it multiple time. He was probably new.

Crab and pork dumpling...

Stir fried noodle shanghai style...after we place our order...we didnt even wait 5 minutes. Probably 2 minutes or less. We wonder if it was someone else who already order or premade. This dish seems kinda little

The foods and prices were average. It would have more satisfying if they had brought out one of dumpling correctly.

Parking may be tough around this neighborhood
author: Julie N.

description:
My bf found this place but when I checked in via Yelp I gave him crap because there was even four stars.  However, as we were seated more and more people filled into the restaurant so that changed my mind about this place.  I had some friends in town and we kind of got one of everything as you will see in the photos.  Our waitress was a cute little lady who gave us some recommendations.  We got, of course, the dumplings.  Unfortunately I really couldn't tell you what they were since the waitress pretty much put in he order for us.  We had one veggie dish, salt and pepper shrimp (my all time fave Chinese dish), sizzling beef (even though I wanted the beef clay pot but the waitress insisted I get this sizzling beef instead), noodles, three different types of dumplings and a side of rice each.  

Now let me tell you it was all so good!  Like every single dish.  I'm so sorry I wasn't able to get the names of every single dish so please look at my photos and tell your waiter/waitress!  I definitely recommend and will definitely come back!  

Oh there is a lunch menu on the weekdays... We were a bit bummed it's not offered on weekends.
author: Nyla K.

description: I really want this place to be amazing. I mean "king" is in the name! But it's just an above average American Chinese place. Had the soup dumplings... they were just ok. Broth kind of 1D, pork only had so much flavor, dumpling wrap didn't feel especially well made or certainly not thin. If you got nothing else going on and it's convenient then why not, but's hardly a destination. Seems like it's more about to go orders than sit down once inside.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
I order only one type of dumpling, and it's the spicy wontons (they are only mildly spicy) which are akin to crack. I've shamelessly taken these to potlucks when I don't have time to cook myself, and I can always see a moment of discovery when people bite in and then demand to know where I got them from. 

The sauce itself makes all the difference and has a peanut base, chili oil, and finely minced pickled vegetables. Alternate bites between garlic sautéed pea shoots and rice and you've got a trifecta of flavor and general happiness.
author: Steph L.

description:
Waitress was super sweet!  Based on Yelp pictures, I ordered the shrimp and chive dumplings and she recommended the pork dumplings in peanut sauce.

Pork dumplings in peanut sauce:  as with all dumplings, these come out steaming hot.  Cut into one and allow it to cool a bit before popping it into your mouth.  You'll be able to enjoy the subtle garlic flavor in the peanut sauce and the tender, juicy pork filing.

Shrimp and chive dumpling:  the skin on these is a bit thicker.  The delicate soy based sauce is dotted with shiny red hot oil drops that lend just a touch of spiciness to the plump shrimp filling.

The flavors are good and portions and price reasonable.  Best to go with at least one other person so you can share and get more!
author: Sondra H.

description: The food quality here is very tasteful compared to other Chinese restaurants. I got the sizzling beef and soup doumling and pan fried. The taste is very memorable. Would of got five stars from me if the place didn't have storage boxes all over the place. Service was friendly.
author: Nacho E.

description:
This place is just mainly for couples and small groups of friends. They have one large table and everything else is just a small table for 4.

Their plates are cheap due to their small size. Again ordering a plate that 2 people can munch on. As far as flavor, very heavy on oil and salt.
author: M C.

description:
I was excited for dumplings, but didn't love this place. For such fluorescent lighting, I was expecting a cheaper bill. The classic dumplings were good but I didn't think the crab & pork ones tasted good - they were weirdly sweet.

I would try the other location if it has similar pricing and a slightly better ambiance.
author: Eve P.

description: the dumplings had no flavor. they were also served underdone!  The service was kind and friendly.  I will not return.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
The Shanghai Style Soup is legit as it gets. Wonderful broth and love the tofu knots instead of noodles. Very good Xiao Long Bao, nice a juicy. The dipping sauce could use a little more vinegar, but I usually like it with more vinegar than the average person. 

Great staff that is super professional and friendly.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Dumplings tastiness: B-
Cleanliness: C
Will only stop by to pick up food if I'm in the area, won't drive all the way there just to eat there. That's my take.
author: Shaz L.

description:
Came here with my Mother who is super picky about where she eats. Especially when it comes to Chinese food. 

I was craving dumplings and was looking for a place that would be good that we could agree on. I found this place on Yelp and decided to give it a shot.

We ordered the sizzling rice soup first. The broth here is pretty amazing and doesn't just taste like salted water. You can tell that there is a level of care and attentiveness to get it just right. The rice was a little off from what I have tried in the past before but it was not a deal breaker. GET THE SOUP. It would be perfect for when you're feeling under the weather, too.


Ordered the Meat Pies which reminded me of a giant-ass-potsticker. I definitely recommend it! Super tasty and filling. Honestly this could be a whole meal in itself with a side of sautéed spinach or the veggie delight in the menu. 

Shangai Dumplings were not the best. They were a little strange for me in overall flavor. Pretty bland to be honest and would not order again even with the soy-ginger sauce that they make you at the table. 

Spicy Shrimp and Chive dumplings were really REALLY good. They were definitely not spicy but the chili sauce gave it a nice "kick." It is topped with green scallions and toasted Sesame seeds.BOMB!
author: T. C.

description:
Ordered to go and I haven't taste the food yet but I know I am not coming back! Customer service sucks! I was looking at the to-go menu and I told the lady the numbers on the menu. She was like "DON'T TELL ME THE NUMBER!" 
Excuse me! You wrote it on your menu, lady!!
author: Kimi Y.

description: If I come back, and there are fortune cookies at the end of dinner for my child, you may get a better rating.  But until you provide some treat at the end for CHILDREN, it will remain a poor review.  Orange slices would even suffice!
author: M L.

description: This is the spot! Order #2, #4 and #7. Forget the rest, these are the essential dishes- it's called dumpling king for a reason. I've been coming here for years, I prefer this location to Balboa's- the food is better , no line out the door, and they take credit cards. Service is great, food is so good- order two #4s while your at it, and be gentle w your chopsticks- don't let them pop.
author: Collin S.

description: This is a great place to eat Chinese food. I always order the chicken friends rice, wonton soup and the shanghai style dumplings. I love this place unlike other Chinese restaurants in San Francisco because the food here is always consistently good. Other Chinese restaurants can be a hit or miss when it comes to flavor. Never once have I come here and been disappointed. Whether they are busy or slow the quality remains the same.
author: Thomas B.

description: Been here many times because it's near city college and its cheap. It's always great to find cheap and great food for a student. I usually get XLB for the pork and the crab. One of each.
author: Nick F.

description:
BEWARE-If I could give "0" stars, I would.  Don't waste your time and money ... go somewhere else.  This is the first time I've ordered food from Shanghai Dumpling King and it will be the last.  Sorry to say but it's some of the worst Chinese food I've ever had.  

Ordered via phone and was told to come at a specific time.  Arrived at appointed time but when I got there my order wasn't ready.   I had to wait, wait, wait, while staff at the rear of the restaurant were composing multiple orders at once, bringing out one item at a time.  Why they don't focus on one order and complete it before moving on to next is beyond me!  By the time I got my full order and got home (a few blocks away) my food was lukewarm at best (egg rolls were cold.)  

Ordered a total of 5 items, all disappointing: 1 pork dish was so dried out it was like eating crunchy popcorn, 2nd item was supposed to be orange beef but I ended up with chicken wrapped in dough & deep fried, egg rolls were cold, other 2 items were passable but just not that good.  All food was bland and not cooked well.

How this place stays in business is absolutely mind boggling.  I wish I had read the Yelp reviews before I tried it.
author: M F.

description: Hang out with friends on a weekday night and ordered almost all suggested food. I would say the vegetarian stuff, steamed bun 素包子, steamed dumplings 蒸饺 fried dumplings 煎饺etc are pretty good. The other recommended dumplings, are okay. Definitely taste good. But not the best in the city. Spicy Wonton etc 油抄手 皮略厚 辣油 o.k. 但是不够辣 没有辣的香气
author: Ming S.

description: The most rude people i have ever meet, food its ok but the taste after been yell from the cook its horrible... not recomended, maybe order on line
author: Ariel Leo L.

description:
I don't know why this place has such low rating, because I think it deserves so much more.
I pretty much come to this place every single time I am in San Francisco. Even a few times a week.  Being from Seattle, Din Tai Fung is the closest place for Xiao Long Bao and Shanghai stir fried noodle, but it will NEVER beat the prices and authentic taste here. 

Get the stir fried noodle or rice cake! You will not regret it! It has a great soy-sauce sweet taste. Xiao long bao is the second best thing. After, chives and pork dumpling (steamed without the hot sauce) is great if you're a chive fan! If you don't like vinegar, I recommend using soy sauce for the complimentary dipping sauce they give you in the beginning. 

If there is a long wait, which I never had to experience, it is DEFINITELY worth the wait. Service was great, for a Chinese restaurant. Waiters kept walking by to see if everything was good or needed more of anything and to take away empty places. We ordered 2 dumplings, 1 noodle dish, and 1 appetizer for a total of $29. I'm so glad this place is so inexpensive for its food.
author: Eva L.

description: Yummy Shanghai soup dumplings, pea sprouts with garlic- lightly cooked, everything delivered quickly. Exactly what we needed!
author: Deirdre S.

description:
HORRIBLE  ! HORRIBLE  ! HORRIBLE  !
RUDE ! Told waitress who is unbelievablely rude I am cancelling my $50 pickup order because of her. 
.
I ordered pickup. I show up 20 mins later, there is 3 people ahead of me. Restaurant half empty.  After a 12 hour day, I decided to sit quietly to wait my turn. The waitress came by told me " You can't sit there You stand and wait for your food ". 
Utter Shock. I told her I wanted to cancel due to her rude communication.  She said,  " Don't talk to me " n pointed to guy helping the others in line. Told her I was leaving because she is too rude.  I left.  Never coming back.
author: Hungry K.

description:
Delicious food and wonderful service! . 
The staff were very helpful and they have a ton of great vegetarian-friendly options.
Couldn't have asked for a better evening!
author: Melissa C.

description:
My bf and I ordered Shanghai Dumpling King on Saturday night through UberEats! It was our first time trying this restaurant and we decided to get three things: xiao long bao (shanghai soup dumplings), pork & vegetable dumplings, and garlic eggplant. The total (with $5 delivery fee) was $28. Not too bad!

I would probably give the food 4 stars but what led to 3 instead was the packaging of the xiao long baos... For everyone who loves them, the best part of a xlb is the soup inside!! Unfortunately, all our dumplings were packed so tightly in a plastic container that when we picked up one, the skin would rip and the soup dripped out. :( Maybe they could package it in a bigger container like i've seen at Kingdom Of Dumpling.

Other than that, the dishes were good. I especially liked the garlic eggplant, which was a little sweet and had a slight kick of spice to it too! The pork & vegetable dumplings were standard, but nothing too special. Definitely a worthy choice on UberEats!
author: Tara A.

description: I came for dumplings ordered dumplings so they brought my dumplings but their dumplings are not dumplings but won ton type of dumplings not to happy & to boot they were not good won ton dumplings
author: wayne b.

description: Neighborhood restaurant with a wide variety of options. Our focus was the soup dumplings. We enjoyed both the Shanghai and Crab/Pork, which were the favorite. The pea shoots were cooked to perfection and the green onion pancake was a hit. Everyone was full and happy!
author: Trudy G.

description:
TLDR - Tasty, affordable dumplings. Get delivery from UberEATS or Caviar to avoid the long wait!

Review is for UberEATS delivery. As someone who hates waiting for a table at a restaurant, it's unlikely I would've tried their dumplings if it weren't for UberEATS or Caviar. I was actually pretty hesitant to order dumplings for delivery because I didn't expect them to arrive fresh and warm, so I was surprised when they were delivered as if they had just come out of the kitchen a few feet away. Prices were really reasonable for the amount of food as well.

* SHANGHAI STEAMED DUMPLING ($6.95, 10pcs) - 4/5
The pork filling was tender, juicy and flavorful, but some of the dumplings were lacking in soupiness. The dumpling skin was thicker than DTF and a little mushy/doughy, but surprisingly capable of holding the dumpling together.

* SPICY CHIVES & PORK DUMPLING ($6.50, 10pcs) - 4/5
Tasty filling as well and same doughy skin. The dumplings weren't spicy but the spicy/garlic sauce was still flavorful.

Overall, solid dumplings. Not the best I've had, but given the price and especially given the convenience and quality of delivery, I'd order again to satisfy my dumpling cravings.
author: Jessie L.

description:
At $6.95 the Twice Cooked Pork lunch special came with rice, a fried eggroll and soup. For another $6.95 the Kung Pao Chicken also came with rice, eggroll and soup and was a much better dish. 
.
Because our meals came at least 15 minutes apart we were barely able to eat together.
.
We also ordered the $6.95 Steamed Shanghai Dumplings which were so over-steamed each one tore thus its soup contents spilled out before a spoon could be place under it. Of 10 pieces we managed to have only two with soup and those were very good. Too bad the other eight were wasted.
.
If I can keep my expectations lower I will return on occasion.
author: Caesar A.

description: The worst restaurant . I had to pick up the food from here . And the front lady was a jerk . Like seriously a jerk . No customer service knowledge , you don't deserve to serve customers .
author: Rachana A.

description: I F******* LOVE THIS place. Best Chinese in town. The dumplings are a must do when in San Francisco or you're just having a bad day and need to eat your feelings on a Friday night. Do not second yourself here, but the ticket take the ride. Mahalo, and enjoy!
author: Sara I.

description:
Favorite place hands down for XLB. Service is not bad for a Chinese restaurant. Fast paced, crowded, but still cozy and CASH ONLY. My favorite Shanghai place.

My go-tos:
-Shanghai Soup Dumplings (duh)
-Pea shoots (why does it have to be so expensive :*()
-Shanghai Style Chow Mein  (thick and chewy like I like it)

Also recommended:
-Pan-fried BBQ pork buns
-Potstickers, huge chewy, lots of skin :) good meat
-Green Onion pancake (not my favorite place to get them though. Too deepfried)
-EGG PUFFFS. mmmm

I've been to this and their second location many times and have brought many people to it. This is my go-to place. I've tried many dishes here and haven't really been disappointed ever.
author: Josie W.

description: Terrible food, after i ate dumplings, my stomach is hurt, and i ran to restroom several times. Moreover, i found something like hair in beef tendon, how horrible!
author: Zhu K.

description:
I liked this place because of its small-restaurant charm. The sizzling rice soup was awesome light comfort food, and filling too, with all that rice. The Shanghai pan-fried buns were mediocre, I wouldn't recommend this dish. The xlb was pretty good. Not too much soup in the dumpling, but good flavor. 

The table next to us had this zha jiang main looking dish with thin noodles. Had me drooooooling! Going back just for that.
author: Maggie G.

description: Update: Currently, did a pick-up! Food was ready quick (15 mins), and it was a big one. Ordered our favorite lamb potsticker! Fish Fillet with salt and pepper. Sugar puffs for desert!
author: J M.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!! Delicious dumplings, and definitely affordable.

Food: spicy wontons, XLB, pan fried reg pork buns (not BBQ one), pork and chives dumplings are must get! 

Spicy wontons aren't spicy but has a creamy peanut sauce very similar to Vietnamese peanut sauce. It's unique but surprisingly addicting. The sauce coats the pork dumplings so perfectly. 

Pan fried reg pork buns is also unique because it's a crispy pork bun for the texture but very appetizing. 

I don't recommend getting noodles dishes because they're bland, portions are small and mostly has garnishes than actual meat and noodles. 

They prefer cash, but there is a card minimum.

Price: affordable considering it's SF. 

Service: 3/5 average but could be more attentive to tables instead of flagging someone down. 

If you order take out, make sure to check your food before leaving because they forgot 2/5 things I ordered... 

Overall, I love this place for their spicy wontons and reg pan fried pork buns. There's no place like it and that's what makes this place so unique!
author: Angela T.

description:
Just tried this place out with Uber Eats. Food was ordered and delivered very quickly. It was exceptionally good and better than I thought it would be.

I got the shanghai rice cakes (delicious and my fave!). Also got the XLB and spicy shrimp dumplings. The XLB were very juicy and still piping hot in the to-go box.

I will definately order from this place again!!
author: Cicely T.

description: Awesome Chinese joint in San Francisco. Dumplings are delicious! Food comes out quickly and the folks that work there are quite friendly. Next time I'm in SF I will be back!
author: Will S.

description:
I recently became a huge fan of Shanghai Dumplings aka "Xiao Long Bao". And some places truly are a hit or miss. My favorite go-to place would be Dumpling Empire in SSF for the Shanghai Dumplings. I love the burst that it provides.

I happened to have a dumpling craving one night and decided to go to Shanghai Dumpling King. Parking is slightly difficult but nothing too extreme. I had to park in the residential area not too far away.

Service is great. The waitress was very nice and attentive. She even gave me some recommendations regarding specials, which is a plus. She was always smiling and made sure I had everything I needed. Very pleasant experience.

What I Ordered:

* Shanghai Dumplings: Nice and plump and filled with delicious broth! The dough was toothsome and filling was nicely seasoned. Perfect dipped in the chili oil!

* Shrimp and Chives Dumpling: Boiled not pan fried. I love the combination of shimp and chives. Dough had a nice texture as well.

* Chicken Wings: San Tung is still better.

Overall I would come back. Dumplings weren't cheap but not too expensive either. I would come back just for the Shanghai Dumplings. It's a little out of the way from where I live but if I was in the area, I wouldn't mind stopping by.
Oh and FYI: they're a cash only establishment; hence the 4-star rating.
author: Ralph N.

description:
This casual restaurant is a nice quiet family run place that has a really great variety of the type of Chinese food dishes I enjoy.  It was a quiet Sunday afternoon (late lunch) so the waitress had time to make recommendations based on our traditional beef chow mein order, and suggested the Shanghai styled noodles.  She also recommended the Thai ice tea.  Their waiter was quick to serve us with water, tea, and our drink orders.  We ordered the spicy chicken wings, XLB, green onion pancakes, and spicy wonton dumplings (plus she didn't judge the 2 of us for ordering so many dishes!).

Our dishes:

Thai iced tea 3/5: Really sweet, even though I'm a sweet tooth, it was much too milky, and I could barely taste the tea.  I even avoided stirring the milk in further, but the tea was already compromised.  

Shanghai noodles with beef 5/5:  I expected this dish to leave the noodles basking in oil, but it was less greasy while still maintaining the flavor.  I love thick noodles and the beef was really tender and not tough or chewy.  The sauce was appropriately salty, and the spinach and lettuce really helped to mop up some of the extra sauce and balance out the savory carb-y and meat-y dish.

Spicy chicken wings 3.5/5: I'm a big fan of Korean style spicy chicken wings, and this Chinese sauce was a bit thick, sort of like gelatin.  It was somewhat flavorful, but not spicy enough for my boyfriend's tastebuds, but the meat was tender, probably locked in by the jelly sauce.

XLB 4.5/5: While others have complained about the thick skin, I found the skin/meat ratio to be good.
