I do generally enjoy a slightly chewier skin so it might just be my personal preference, so I'll just affirm that this skin was thicker than the XLBs at Koi Palace and Din Tai Fung.  The meat inside was really fresh and obviously used fresh pink meat instead of the dried out previously frozen grayer meat that you sometimes see in dumpling innards, and the soup was flavorful, so this definitely met my expectations.

Green onion pancakes 4/5: These pancakes had a unique texture, and were crispier in a more uniform way than the usual stereotypical green onion pancake.  These are more crispy without being flaky, and the batter is cooked a lot more uniformly than usual.  This was also less oily and greasy than the usual pancake, but also less doughy (and I prefer the doughier texture) and was adorned with sesame seeds on top.  I would prefer the typical green onion pancake, but this was still worth trying.

Spicy wonton dumplings 4/5: This dish was again, not too spicy, but the meat was really juicy.  For those who enjoy a thinner skin that's not chewy doughy, this is the appropriate dish for you.

This was a worthwhile experience even though we'd made a trek all the way from downtown SF to satisfy our dumpling cravings so I'll be back.
author: Kathy T.

description:
Came for a late lunch on a Saturday around 3p.m. and it wasn't very busy. I think there were only 2 other groups eating there. The food is pretty average and service is okay good. 

We had the xiao long bao, the shrimp and chive dumplings, and a couple other dishes that weren't that memorable. The xiao long bao needed more soup and the shrimp and chive dumplings could have had more flavor. 

The only good thing is that we found parking pretty easily a block away on the street. 

Not the best place for dumplings.
author: Mai Y.

description:
What I remember most: the sweetest service from the sweetest lady that works there. Thank you for making my birthday that much more sweeter :)

I prefer this location over the Balboa Ave location because I don't feel rushed to eat and gtfo. Also more elbow room here. The tables are spaced out and the waiters come and check up on you periodically, while refilling the teapot and water glasses.

A few weeks ago, I ate here with two friends to celebrate a very casual birthday. We ordered the XLBs (of course), spicy wontons, dan dan mien, and spicy eggplant. The eggplant was surprisingly very good! Not too oily, but very spicy. The XLBs were juicy and flavorful - you can never go wrong. The dan dan mien was extra nutty (loaded up with peanuts) and the spicy XLBs was more on the tangier spicy than a ka-pow! hit you in the throat spicy. Needless to say, there were no leftovers.
author: Annie S.

description:
I didn't know Shanghai Dumpling King opened a second location. I found this restaurant while looking for a lunch spot somewhere on the way to cow palace for the dicken's fair (which I highly recommend by the way.) 

This location serves the same food as the original, and it's a lot more spacious and don't require much of a wait which is definitely a plus! However, I must say the dumplings are good, but not as good. Maybe it's been a while since I've been to the SDK in outer richmond, but I remembers the XLBs to be a lot soupier. We ordered 2 orders at this restaurant (20 total) and none of them contained soup :(

Price wise, it's the same as the original location. I'd say it's decent for an okay lunch but I wouldn't come out of my way to get XLBs here.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Just what dumplings should be. I enjoyed the sugar puffs too. 
Excellent service. Fresh food.
author: Juliana R.

description:
Ordered shanghai chow mien, green onion pancake, pan fried buns, & spicy wonton for lunch. Food came out extremely fast! Chow mien & pan friend buns was good. I've had better green onion pancake. The spicy wonton was nothing like I expected. The sauce was more like a peanut sauce; it was not spicy at all. 

Overall good food for the price.
author: Xe X.

description:
In a single line: Solidly average.

We came by this restaurant because Hong Dong or whatever it's called across the street had issues. Heard it was pretty good, so why not give it a shot? The service was good, so let's just get down to the food.

Xiaolong Bao: Decided on this over regular dumplings. It does take some skill to make these and much like the next couple dishes, I use it to gauge how good their food is. These came out with barely any soup inside, but the flavors were there. Nothing that would get me to tell my friends about.

Spicy Beef Stew Noodle: This was very much like a regular beef stew noodle at any other Chinese restaurant. I suppose I was expecting a Taiwanese version. This wasn't spicy, the noodles were on the brink of being mushy and the tendon pieces were completely stiff - they did not cook it long enough to soften it. On top of this, they didn't cut the beef across the grain, so coupling that with the short cook time, it was tough.

Dan Dan Noodles: Wife had this. She thought this other joint in the Sunset district was better, which I've tried before and that was just okay.

Beef Chow Fun: I always order this dish whenever it's a new restaurant. This is not an easy dish to make right and shows the skill level of the cook. The cook isn't that skilled. The noodles didn't have the right brown color to indicate how much soy sauce was used. Wasn't dry enough, but rather greasy, so too much oil was used and the wok wasn't hot enough. Other things noted were that the dish itself was quite small and they used sugar which has no place in this dish.

Overall, I'd rate this 2.5 as it is so very average compared with all these dumpling joints that sprung up in the city in the last couple years. I would only visit this place if I lived nearby, which I don't. Won Kok next door has much better food, but cost twice as much. Slim pickings in this area.
author: Bor C.

description:
Came here once with a friend for lunch.

We ordered a ton of dumplings:
- Xiao long bao: decent taste, pretty average compared to other XLB
- chive and pork dumplings: pretty good
- the spicy wonton: interesting, but tasted very off

Overall, food quality was pretty average compared to other dumpling places in SF.
author: Alvin W.

description:
The food here is absolutely delicious!  The service is friendly but slow, and the decor could be nicer...but the dumplings are where it's at!

We liked each and every one of the dishes we ordered:

1) Shrimp and chive dumplings in peanut sauce (amazing!)
2) Shanghai dumplings ("classic" and tasty)
3) Crab dumplings (great)
4) Pork buns (good)
5) Spicy wontons (awesome)
6) Pea shoots with garlic (a flavorful veggie side)

The service was a little mixed.  They were slow to greet us when we entered, and then after we were seated, they took a while to take our order.  On the other hand, the food came out quickly, and the staff was friendly and polite.

The decor is a little stale - replacing the old sticky carpet would a long way - but it's generally clean and pleasant.

Come here for the amazing dumplings - you will not be disappointed!
author: Barnali D.

description: Recently discovered this restaurant right in my neighborhood - and want to let folks know it is quite tasty, attentive service and low key - I've been a few times now and though it gets busy, I've not had to wait long to sit and get my order - they seem to do more take out than eat in service.  Besides the namesake Shanghai soup dumplings I really like their black sesame rice dumplings (for dessert).
author: Jeff H.

description: This is the second time. I ordered Pen Fried bun, chow fun, stir fried bean sprout, and sweet dumpling desert for 2 people. The pan fried buns turned out to be a steamed bun re-fried. The bun is not supposed to be steamed. It should be cooked directly in hot cast iron pan. The sweet dumpling has very thick wrapper, feel like eating a big rice ball with only a teaspoon of filling inside. The soup is full of sugar, even my 7 years old cannot drink it.  Don't think there will be 3rd visit.
author: Lei L.

description:
Definitely the least crowded of all the dumpling places in SF. We got the veggie dumplings, chive & pork dumplings, dan dan noodles, Shanghai soup dumplings, and eggplant.  

All were pretty decent! The dan dan noodles portion size was kind of small, so keep that in mind if you have a bigger group. Surprisingly, my favorite part of the meal was the eggplant! Piping hot and fresh off the pan, slightly sweet and tangy sauce, and perfect level of spiciness.

I'll definitely be coming back to try out all the other dumplings. Staff was pretty attentive and always checking in to see if we needed more tea or if everything was good. Definitely a great place for a cheap dinner!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Having an on-campus final at CCSF, I took the bus down to outer mission a bit early to get some studying done beforehand. Shanghai Dumpling King was where I chose to do that and also grab some lunch at the same time. 

I tried two things here, an order of the XLB and an order of the spicy fried wings. The XLB was average and acceptable. It wasn't great but it was decent enough and had a thin wrapper that held together and decent tasting soup. 

The wings, on the other hand, were aweful. Only one in the entire batch was actually crispy and some of them were not even cooked all the way through! No idea how that is acceptable but I didn't eat much of it once I discovered that. Fortunately the waitress noticed it and comped the wings from my bill but still, that is just not cool. That's how you get salmonella!

Overall, I had a bad experience here and will not be returning. Risking getting sick? No thank you. "Methinks not."
author: Mark O.

description: I am so lucky that this place is only two blocks away from me! The only thing about this place that is disappointing to me, is that they don't deliver! They by far, are appropriately named! I was ill and ordered their seafood soup with shrimp dumplings! OMG! The soup was excellent, but the dumplings were utterly Amazing! The dumplings were bursting with Shrimp! The dumplings were so fresh! They were not goey, or "dough like," they were tender! Though there were only eight dumplings, it tasted like there were sixteen, as I had to eat them in halves! Simply divine!
author: Veronika F.

description:
The shanghai dumplings were exceptional. Juicy and soupy inside. Yum. Got that and the shrimp and chives dumpling per the waiter's recommendation saying that these two items were the most popular. I will definitely come back and try other items on the menu.
There's complimentary tea, great service, and great food. 5 stars.
author: Jaime F.

description:
This is probably the worst Shanghai restaurant that I've ever been to. The waiter who sat us was really nice. But the waitress who took my order was extremely rude. I ordered in Cantonese and I take it that she didn't understand me because she kind of gave me a blank stare. I decided to make it easier and tell her the number on the menu and she says to me "don't tell me the number. I want to know the name of the dish." Whaaaaat? Did she really just talk to me like that? There was no need to be rude and talk to me in that tone when I was only trying to make things easier for her. (She didn't have a notepad or anything with her) I was going to suck it up because maybe she was just having a bad day but she had a smile on her face and was super nice to all the regulars who came in after me. Ummm... excuse me ... I'm a paying customer too ... the food wasn't all that great either but it's edible. Two stars for the nice waiter who sat us and for the food. Negative stars for everything else. I tipped the 15% but sorry, I will not be coming back.

*I do not recommend the green onion pancake. That was the only inedible thing that I ordered. It was way too flakey. I pretty much wasted that dish
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Last Sunday my friends and I ate here for brunch and it was okay.  We ordered green onion pancake,  Wonton soup, spicy wontons,  hot and sour soup,  pork steam buns and the sauteed egg plants. 

Green onion pancake: way too dry..  

Wonton soup: this would've been amazing if there were soup in the Wonton.  All the soup leaked out the bottom causing everything to get soggy.

Spicy wonton: The wontons weren't spicy at all,  but had a yummy peanut sauce on the top.  Kind of like a Asian salad dressing? 

Pork steamed buns were yummy! 

Hot and sour soup & the vegetable dumplings I didn't try,  but my friends said it was pretty good. 

Overall this place was good... Not sure if I would go again.  I feel like SF has way more to offer.
author: Michelle L.

description: Service and food was great! And the the price was right on. Ordered the dumplings(shao long bao), steamed pork buns, spinach with garlic, and the Dan Dan noodles. Will come back for more!
author: M D R 1.

description:
Dumpling Galore! I could never be able to find a place like this in SD and being a good tourist trying to go where locals eat.

After my friends picked me up from the airport, we were craving for some good food and since we were near by, everyone said they had the best dumplings ever! Well of course I'm going to try!

If I ever had a dumpling dream, I would dream about their Xiao long bao! I could of ate the whole basket if no one else didn't want anymore because it was delicious! We also ordered the stir fried noodles and pork buns with peanut sauce as well. Although I couldn't understand the majority of what everyone was saying, I didn't really care because I was trying to get the full out of body experience with the dumplings! Such a perk of living in San Francisco!
author: Maddie M.

description: Ordered dinner here via UberEATS. Fast delivery in horrible weather. Thumbs up! Ordered preserved eggs with tofu, veggie noodle soup, bean sprouts stir fry with garlic, I also ordered seafood tofu soup but received wonton soup instead, which was not bad. Food was decent!
author: Vee V.

description:
This is one of the places I want to keep secret because it's that good, and it's so close to home. I would hate it if lines started coming out the door!
After coming here twice, my must haves are the xlb's and the Dan Dan noodles. Both dishes are just so amazing. The spicy dumplings are good, but I can do without them. Prices are pretty cheap. Three dishes for two people ended up being under or around $20, and I had leftovers to take home! The customers here are pretty diverse, and it gets pretty packed around dinner time. I know that I will be a regular here for sure!
author: Corinna T.

description:
Great prices for the food and quality...

Must try the xiao long bao...spicy tendons and the Shanghai noodles

Worth a return trip
author: Leslie Y.

description: My bf and his roommate loves this place for the price. They got me a bunch of take out and I think the food is decent. We got the crab meat shanghai dumping, general's chicken, sweet and sour chicken, and pot stickers. The shanghai dumplings were okay but was sticky so the juice was all lost before it got into my mouth. I think what they could have done was put a lettuce on the bottom of the box. I like the to go boxes they give though, because they make great tupperware. I'm dying to try the pan fried buns and shanghai fried noodles that my bf will soon get me in the future! Hehe. I'm so stoked to try those! (I will write a review after I try those!)
author: Amy Y.

description: So so good! We ordered a mix of dumplings and they were amazing! Definitely a place to go.
author: Eric F.

description:
We ordered some dumplings, chicken fried rice and some braised prawns.
All was delivered half cold.
Also, the prawns were not even entirely cooked but still half way rare. We had to leave that out.
Dumplings were average and we really had to look for the kitchen in the fried rice.
I would suggest to find another place to eat or to get delivery.
author: Brice D.

description: Ordered via UberEATS and never received my order. Maybe they were just too busy to deliver my beef chow fun and Dan Dan noodles. It turns out they waited over an hour to notify Uber that they couldn't fulfill my order. Thanks Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Tim G.

description:
The place is called Shanghai Dumpling King. 

Don't order the noodles, or a vegetable dish, or even the chicken wings. 

Order the Dumplings. 

We ordered: 
Wontons with spicy peanut sauce: 5/5. 
Shanghai dumplings (XLB): 4/5. These were actually delicious, but there wasn't quite enough soup inside.
Pork and chive dumplings: 3/5. They were very good as well, but compared to the others the skin was a lot thicker which I don't prefer. 

This is now our new go-to for dumplings.
author: Andy C.

description: The hostess/waitress/owner just YELLED AT ME for standing in front of the cash register instead of another area to pick up my order. I think she thought I was an Uber Eats or delivery driver because she calmed the f*ck down when I gave her stink eye. But check yourself if you think yelling at customers is acceptable... -.-
author: kiwi l.

description:
300th REVIEW.

Trying to avoid driving on 280 or 101 trying to get into South City from downtown on a busy Friday afternoon, I took it to Waze to take me through the city streets to get myself to Irving Street so I could get myself some T-pumps on that gorgeous afternoon. Since I've never really drove through the city streets I took my sweet time and I mean, it was crazy hilly. I was absolutely not used to it. 

While trying to get to my destination, I was raving about how I wanted dumplings but that Shanghai Dumpling Shop in Millbrae was too far for that. So here I am driving and pulling up to this red light, AND BAM! 

DUMPLINGS were in my face, well it was the corner restaurant with the sign that said Shanghai Dumpling King and I took a hard right turn and then pulled over right so I could park. Tip: It's a one way so you can just turn right and cut left and park on the left side because it's residential parking and FREE! Anyways, it was around 315PM so I wasn't sure if they were opened or if they were closed. Took a chance, walked in AND YES! Even though it was that lunch break, they were opened the doors were opened and they were VERY welcoming to have diners come in. 

I was quickly seated and handed menus. They're your typical Chinese dumpling shop with a couple of specialities and the rest is just your regular Chinese dining menu with stir fry, rice and noodles, vegetables, and so forth. I was just really there for the dumplings so I ordered: 

Shanghai Steamed Dumpling (10) for (5.95) - Very soupy and was filled with meat! I really enjoyed this and I was genuinely surprised about how much I liked these xlb dumplings. There were ten pieces AND under 6 dollars. I mean, that's cheap AND delicious.

Beijing Style Boiled Chives Dumplings (10) for (5.50)- The skin was super doughy and I think they might have over-boiled it, but it didn't take away from the flavors. My other half who doesn't enjoy chives actually really liked these dumplings. I didn't pick the spicy one since I knew it was just the same thing but with sauce drizzle.  You get 10 very filling dumplings for an absolute steal! 

Sweet Bun Deep Fried (4) for (2.25)- They made this perfect!!! I mean, it was super sweet and crunchy and deep fried on the outside, while the inside was so moist just like asian bread. The four pieces were huge, almost the size of a young child's fist. I guess that's not a very good comparison but it was a good size. Plus, the condense milk was REAL not watered down, but thick and syrupy, melting with the heat of the fried buns. Even better than Shanghai Dumpling Shop.

I ordered the same things as I usually would at the SDS, but I enjoyed Shanghai Dumpling King a whole lot. I mean my entire meal plus tip was all under twenty dollars! So unreal I don't eat that cheap but man, was that well worth every bite and every cent was well spent. The staff is super nice. The restaurant was decently clean and the bathrooms by SF standards was really clean for what I've seen. 

I highly suggest this location and I think it's a lot less busy than the one on Balboa, which is an extra plus. They are both the same so why not pick the better of the two and one with better parking access. If for some reason I ever drove into and through the city like I did, definitely would come back and settle in myself with two orders of those Shanghai Steamed Dumplings. So cheap, so delicious and flavorful and better than my originally favorite location. Oh how such a simple experience can change my entire foodie world.
author: Winnie G.

description:
In the mood for some comfort, home style Chinese food?   S.D.K. hits spot every time! It is my fiance and my go-to spot for dumplings and Chinese food.  What's even better, is that she's a vegetarian, and I'm basically a carnivore, and SDK has plentiful delicious options for both of us! You must try the soup dumplings when you come! 

IFinally, the service is truly outstanding, and there's a nice homie/comfy vibe inside.   This makes it a perfect spot for a nice conversational dinner with friends!
author: Matt C.

description: Another place I'm putting on my BANNED LIST!!!! Food quality is horrible. Flavors are mediocre. Service is lacking. They're too busy with their to-go business with Uber Eats and EAT24 etc. Near the end of my meal, I found a strand of hair in my tofu and a small bug in another dish. This place is HORRIBLE!!!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
I was a bit disappointed with the dumplings here. I tried the xlb, and the crab and pork dumplings. The flavor was good but not great. What really peeved me was that several of the dumplings I ate had no soup but the dumpling wrappers were pretty thick.

I also tried the spicy chicken wings that came in a sweet chili sauce but it seemed like bottled sauce. The chicken wings were perfectly fried. However, after visiting, I looked at some yelp photos and noticed other spicy chicken wings were served in a much darker, molasses-like sauce. I'm not sure if there are different sauces but our waiter never said anything.

I did enjoy the sugar egg puffs. Sweet and custardy with a crispy exterior and fluffy interior. 

Service was friendly and I was able to find residential parking nearby.
author: Maya S.

description:
Though it's an expansion, the food does not live up to it's Balboa Street location.

For our party of two, we ordered three dishes and we did go home with a bit of leftovers:
*Xiao long bao (Shanghai dumplings, 10 pieces, $5.95) - The skin was thin and the pork filling was tasty, but half/more than half of the dumplings came broken and missing the broth.  Unacceptable if this is your specialized dish.
*Prawn & chive dumpling special (8 pieces, $9.95) - The skin was too thick and tasted doughy.  The filling consisted of mostly chives with a tiny piece of shrimp, not prawn.
*Stir fried Shanghai noodles - Delicious and the best dish of the meal.  Fat, chewy noodles are stir fried and mixed with shredded cabbage, beef, and chicken.  

Service sucked.  Typical Chinese restaurant.  The waitress was very impersonal and unfriendly.  She took our order and walked away without saying anything.  After we were done eating, we sat there for a bit without being offered our check or a box even though we were the only people in the restaurant.  I finally had to wave her down to bring our check and a box.

Make the extra drive to their Balboa Street location.  You'll be happier. 

WHAT TO KNOW:
*$20 minimum for credit cards (Visa or Mastercard)
*Street parking
*We were the only people in the restaurant at 2pm on a Thursday
author: Nicole S.

description:
This is my go to Chinese place. I'm Chinese so I can vouch for the food here. My usuals that I get EVERY  time are 
-spicy fish fillet 
-braised string beans 
-spicy wontons 
-spicy fish soup Sichuan style (if you're really hungry) 

Can't go wrong with this restaurant.
author: Jamie Z.

description: Ordered delivery on yelp eats. Made the mistake ordering for one despite $25 min. The amount of food you can order for $25 is insane, which is a plus if you don't mind left overs. Got the combo rice, that was disappointingly tasteless. Otherwise the dumplings, vegetable eggs rolls and especially the pork chow mein were delicious! Delivery was prompt
author: Vanessa D.

description: I dropped by for a quick to-go order of the Spicy wontons in a creamy, peanut sauce based on the exceptional Yelp reviews. These were indeed incredible delicacies. I've never tasted anything quite like it. The restaurant itself looked pleasant and quite bustling for a Sunday afternoon. Will definitely come back to sample more of the menu.
author: William H.

description:
Shanghai Dumpling King

It's so nice to come visit SF and get my dumpling fix and feel satisfied when I leave.

I always order garlic green beans and scallion pancake on the side to go with my dumplings.

The only drawback is I wish the dumplings were bigger! Maybe it's just a west coast thing.
author: Faithmari L.

description:
I haven't really found a place to eat XLB in SF and then my friends discovered the one on Balboa in Richmond and then we came to this location to have dinner one day. Place was packed and don't forget to write your name on the clip board so the spaces so accordingly. 

We ordered two orders of XLB, pan fried dumplings, crab and pork dumplings and a dry beef chow fun for some substance.

Everything was tasty and came out fresh and hot. Their sauces are good too for dipping your dumplings in.
author: Tiff C.

description: Cheap and tasty, win-win. Pork XLB was tasty, the skin was soft and chewy. Shanghai soup was okay. Shrimp dumpling was amazing. Bean sprouts - comes fried with garlic and onion! Vegetable dumpling - would skip.
author: Christina T.

description: I'd love to be able to give this place more stars.. except we never even got our food! We went here on a Sunday afternoon and waited over 40 minutes after ordering before the toddlers and adults in our group starting to get very antsy & we asked when our food would be ready. Turns out they 'lost' our order and asked us what we ordered so they could place it again. They balked at us when we asked if they'd be willing to provide an comped appetizer or any already made dishes while asking us to continue waiting so we chose to leave. Worst customer service. I realize that most people that dine here as well as the restaurant owners won't ever read this review or even care- but I felt like I had to warn other potential customers
author: Sarah L.

description: The xiao long Bao, Dan Dan mien and the spicy dumplings in chili oil are the best here! Why go all the way to the sunset or Richmond when there is one on Monterey ave? The xiao long Bao has a nice soup when you bite into it! The dan Dan mien is a generous portion with a really good meat sauce! The spicy dumplings have a really good sauce as well! The prices are very reasonable here too.
author: Janet Z.

description: A few more Caviar app orders since the initial review... The app has limited options, but everything I've tried has been good.
author: Paulina F.

description:
The peanutty spicy dumpings are delicious. Great portion sizes too. 

One of the best dumpling places in the city.
author: Nm B.

description:
It's interesting seeing a Shanghainese restaurant opening up in this neighborhood, especially because they're typically located in Outer Richmond or Parkside.

The xiao long baos here were decent. The pork meat was moist and juicy. But the soup was oily, bland, and not seasoned enough. I had to douse the dumpling in the ginger-soy sauce mixture to get some flavor.

The vegetable and pork dumplings were pretty good. They were large and meaty, with a generous amount of filling, majority being the pork and not the green onion.

The vegetarian goose, which is vegetables (typically mushrooms) wrapped with bean curd, was very salty. There was barely any mushrooms, so the whole dish consisted mainly of the bean curd. Don't get me wrong -- I like bean curd, but the proportions were really off in this appetizer, so it was disappointing.

Since Shanghai Dumpling King is relatively new (opened early April 2013), their prices are still pretty low, compared to other Shanghainese restaurants that have been around longer. Also, there is no wait time during peak lunch hours on weekends! If I'm in the neighborhood, I would come back for an affordable, satisfactory meal. But SDK isn't my go-to restaurant for delicious xiao long baos.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
I haven't been here in a while because their food went downhill, as my previous review stated. Such as lacking flavor, and their dumpling skins are so thick that all you're eating is dough. 

But I've failed to find a new dumpling place and I decided, "Why not. Maybe they went back to how they made things when I was obsessed with this place." And lo and behold, it did! I was ecstatic that their XLB was flavorful as always, and their spicy wonton wasn't completely made out of the skin wrapping anymore. *tears of joy* And possibly, they tweaked the sauce to the spicy wontons a bit and I actually like it a bit more.

I'll once again crave Shanghai dumpling king :) Happy face.
author: Harriet W.

description:
XLB at Shanghai Dumpling King - My favorite. It's my go to restaurant for valentine's day and anniversaries. 

I've been a patron at the Balboa location for sometime and finally decided to try this location. Here's my thoughts: 
1. Parking - Way easier than Balboa. Parking at some points of time probably could be challenging, but there were a lot more options and the area was not very congested. 
2. Wait Time - No wait time when I came on a Saturday at lunch time 
3. Flavor Profile - After ordering the green beans and XLB - same taste as the Balboa location

For just the above items, it deserved 5 stars. 

Now I was torn between giving this place 2 or 3 stars. As many other yelpers have indicated, probability of getting a XLB with soup in it is pretty slim. In about an order of 10, you will have maybe 2 that have soup in it while all others have leaked out. At that point you might as well just get regular dumplings.

Overall this is a good place if you want to trick yourself into eating XLB and also enjoy some tasty chinese food. However, check out other locations if you actually want to eat soup dumplings.
author: Keri N.

description:
Better than the original. No wait. Parking is a bit easier.

Same low prices ($5.95 for 10 xlbs), same waitstaff 

- BUT - 

I think they have a different (and better) kitchen now. The cooks seem to be a lot better at making the XLBs here. It's not as thick as the Balboa location, dumplings are meatier and extra juicy. Skip the dan dan mein, it was terrible. The leftovers are still sitting in my fridge and will most likely just end up in compost. The noodles were garbage. It tasted like they weren't even rinsed after being boiled.
Waiter was able to make some great recommendations to my siblings. We went with the honey beef filet. Excellent amout of "wok hei" or wok heat going on because the beef was slightly crisp and tender and slightly sweet yet savory.
author: Susy C.

description: My first time ordering from this restaurant. Lunchtime. I ordered Seafood dumpling soup and Green Onioncake. Cakes were cold...I opened them immediately, which means they were sitting around before I ordered. Not tasty either. Soup was bland and the dumplings were thick and tastleless. For a restaurant that calls itself dumpling king, you would think that they knew how to make dumplings. They don't.
author: Phern H.

description: I would say, this the Chinese dishes from this restaurant cannot be called Chinese dishes, maybe American Chinese dishes will be better, as  a Chinese, I never eat the worse food than it.
author: Ying L.

description: I was here for a birthday dinner. The ambiance is nice and the staff was really friendly. I liked the salad bar, but the meat was similar to Espetus. I believe that Espetus boasts a wider selection of meats. Street parking is tough, it is better to Uber in. Overall it was a good experience
author: Dirty S.

description: This place is gross. I tried the XLB and the meat was kinda pink still. So I microwaved it. There was no juice in any of XLB. Drunken chicken was alright but no salt/flavor to it. Would not order anything from here.  Everything is just bland but decent pricing.
author: Ann L.

description: awsome selection of dumplings and other chinese fare dishes !! located in cute part of sf with decent parking or transit options to get there
author: John R.

description:
The food is fantastic and even though it is dirty as hell, I'd still give it 4 stars. 

- Shanghai dumplings (of course), 
- spicy won tons, 
- lion's head soup, 
- sautéed green beans, 
- noodle dishes, 
- fried fish
- pork & chives dumpling
- honey beef

Some dishes could be a miss like beef with broccoli which is a lot of it is due to low quality beef and that is why I order honey beef instead which is made with more expensive and higher quality beef ...
author: Lo F.

description: Love the soup dumpling here! Parking is hard to find, but we were able to get a table with no wait on Thursday evening. Will come back again!
author: H S.

description: The General Taos Chicken was extremely tasteful and had a great crunchy texture to it. As for the dumplings they were are delicious, however I wish they had a bigger selection of dumplings.
author: Dianna C.

description:
My mommy and I came here on a sunny afternoon for lunch. Upon arrival, they were somewhat packed. It was a bit unusual that a slightly packed restaurant was awfully quiet. I'm not complaining, my mommy and I still had a great time.
We ordered their infamous XLBs, Shanghai Rice Cakes with Pork and Veggies, and Garlic Pea Sprouts. These dishes were not bad at all. My only complaint is that the Rice Cakes and Pea Sprouts were drenched in so much oil. As for the XLBs, it was good... but not as good as other XLBs in the city. The skin was thick, and the meat/soup was a bit more sweet than savory.  
Overall, this is somewhere I wouldn't mind eating aging, but it's definitely not a place I would crave.
author: Emily L.

description:
Be prepared. The food at Shanghai Dumpling King takes just a little longer than at other restaurants. This is directly due to 2 factors: 1. They have to steam the dumplings, which is a slower method of cooking.

The restaurant is lackluster, with enough niceties to let you know you aren't eating at your own house. The real big ticket experience here is large party, Chinese dumplings. You get 10 standard dumplings for $5.50. That equals 100 for $55. There's nowhere you can get that volume of food, family style, with this good of quality. Beers are about $3, tea is free, and all the other dim sum style food is 4-7$ per plate of 3-10.

There are more expensive dishes, served as single meals. These aren't worth nearly the deal the dumplings are, unless you come for lunch. The lunch special is a smoking hot deal.

All in all, there are a few things that can make every trip completely perfect. The pork and shrimp dumplings, the spicy pork dumplings, the onion pancake, the braised green beans, the bbq pork buns, the soup dumplings, and the crispy puffs for desert.

For $40 you can feed 4 people till they're fat, and still have leftovers.
author: Dick K.

description: We got a takeout and it was very disappointing.  The chili oil in dumplings was nonexistent.  The szechuan style fish filet was a joke, it was a few pieces of filet floating in soysauce water and no spicy oil to be found anywhere.  The rice cake stir-fry was undercooked and the pieces of rice cakes were still neatly stuck together as they came out from a frozen package.
author: Jessica N.

description:
I came here with my family on a Saturday night around 7:30pm and there was no wait. . We were able to leave here with four full bellies, spending under $10 a person! The food was delicious! We ordered the Shanghai style crispy salt pancake $5.25, Shanghai steamed dumplings (10 in an order) $5.95, Pan fried Pork buns, Pork w/ Preserved Vegetable fried rice cakes $6.95, Stir Fried Noodles Shanghai style $6.5, and a Sweet Soy Bean Milk $1.5. I would order it all again except for the Shanghai style crispy salt pancake. Food came out pretty quickly and service was prompt. I can't wait to come back!


$20 minimum for visa and master charge.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
PARKING - not too hard to find, park in residential areas, just a few block walk

SERVICE - Super cool lady that sat us down. Homeboy server came to help us out with the dumpling ordering ... apparently we ordered the wrong item that we wanted... good thing he made sure, "dumpling with soup." HAHA 

DUMPLINGS - Drools! Delish! Dip it in ginger, soy sauce, and vinger - 100% delish!

OVERALL: That's all we had.. just dumplings!
author: Mindy Y.

description: Pretty bummed - ordered the Glazed Walnut Shrimp expecting something super delicious and honey glazed. Instead, it's deep fried shrimp covered in warm mayonnaise and iceberg lettuce. Tastes like a McChicken for this reason.
author: Julia O.

description: These guys are as good as it gets in terms of managing orders even when it is busy beyond comprehension. Very hard workers. The restaurant is nothing special visually but food is good and service efficient. Parking is limited in this neighborhood.
author: Stefan T.

description:
I ordered Shao Lon Bao, salty duck, Shanghai Chow Mein & honey Glazed Beef. Food came out pretty fast since its a weekday. Shao Lon Bao was a little on the sweet side, but it's ok. The Chow Mein was too soft and it should've be a little harder. They made udon style! Honey Glazed beef taste good, however the beef is a little chewy. 

For someone who eats Shanghainess food all the time.....I think it's fair to give the 3 stars!
author: Jaylene L.

description: This is hands down my favorite Chinese food place ever! I'm a vegetarian and usually have trouble finding things at Chinese restaurants that I actually love, but this place has lots of great options. The vegetarian dumplings are my favorite!
author: Janice B.

description: I've lived in his neighborhood for 7 years and somehow had never been here, until a friend tipped me off that they have vegetarian steamed buns, which are surprisingly hard to find in SF (almost every other Chinese place only offers them with pork or other meat fillings). We also got the vegetarian steamed dumplings, eggplant with garlic sauce, and the "vegetarian goose" from the appetizer menu, which is tofu skin stuffed with mushrooms and served cold. Everything was delicious, the service was friendly, and our bill was only about $30. We look forward to coming back!
author: Gaelen X.

description: Ummm... the spicy wonton. The Shanghai soup dumpling, of course the pork bun...everything was delicious.
author: Angelic S.

description:
We came with some friends who were in town for a visit. We ordered onion pancakes, fried dumplings, steam pork buns, Shanghai style noodles, vegetable, fried pork buns, and rice cake. Onion pancakes were a bit too dry. Portions of the vegetables and rice cake were small.  However, the dishes were good. 

The waiters could do a better job of serving. We had to ask for almost everything: serving spoons, water refill, forks, etc. The owner was so busy taking orders for take out and from eat-in customers. She had to stop three times to finish taking our orders.
author: P C.

description:
The name 'Shanghai Dumpling King' is a little too ambiguous for me. So... are you... The Shanghai Dumpling King because... you eat lots of 'em?... You rule a kingdom of little dumpling citizens? You make the best Shanghai dumplings? Which one is it? 

I had to ask because your name is very inconsistent with your product.  Your XLB aka Xiao Long Bao aka Shanghai dumpling is, quite frankly, disappointing. So I'll have to exercise my power in the Kingdom of Yelp n "rule" out the false impression that you make the best Shanghai dumplings... You should give up your title as King, hand over your crown, n relieve the throne for your own good.

Your XLB is rather stingy on that treasure chest of juicy soupy goodness.  The bao that holds the meat n soup doesn't hold up very well also, causing the soup to leak creating little moats on my plate.  It makes me cry.  I guess it would make sense if those moats were meant to protect the dumpling n its inhabitants from being eaten.  The bao is most often times soggy and lack that light enjoyable chew.  Everything about a great XLB is nonexistent here.

Although XLBs are usually precious little bites that define the greatness of a dumpling empire for me, here it only confuses me because their XLBs don't reflect their title.  Their other dishes are pretty good... Just not the Shanghai XLB dumplings.  You can never go wrong with their traditional Shanghai style stir fried thick noodles or their Dan Dan Noodles smothered in a soy flavored spicy sauce with ground pork.  Their thinly sliced spicy beef tendons are quite an appetizing treat that's a must for all you Asian foodies.  I'm also a sucker for their fish fillets in a tongue numbing spicy oil.  

The owner is always friendly n serves with a smile while accommodating to a guest's every request.  You just can't go wrong with a quick bite here.  

The name Shanghai Dumpling King might not be fitting here while their XLB is Suh King but coming for a taste of Shanghai should nonetheless get your savory lips Smaa King.
author: Colin M.

description: The service is the best!!!!! All are nice Chinese. The food is yummy and also cheap!!!!!
author: LiTing H.

description: Was craving for Shrimp Egg Foo Young and I happened to be near by. Decided to come in and asked if they make it. Duh, it's Chinese Restaurant. For the size I received wasn't worth $13. It was salty, bland, and didn't even have sprouts. Overall nasty food! First and last time I come here.
author: Junray S.

description:
A nice small dumpling shop that doesn't get too much foot traffic. The food was relatively cheap as well and you got a decent amount of dumplings. You're not going to find much in decor though.

We tried a variety of dishes. They were all delicious.

The spicy wontons had an interesting flavor. They were juicy and I wanted to eat a lot of these.

The xiao long bao weren't as soupy as I wanted but the flavor was still good and succulent.

The vegetable dish we got was just sauteed in oil and garlic, but that's standard of a lot of Chinese vegetables.
author: Danielle C.

description:
The Shanghai Dumpling King is a good restaurant, formerly the location of "Happy Palace" and across the street from the location formerly of "Emmy's" on Monterey Blvd, this seems to be the heir apparent neighborhood Chinese restaurant (with the China Wok down the street closed out of business as well).

The XIAO LONG BAO (Shanghai Dumping) for which this is named is good, and priced fair, since you get 10 (ten) per order.  It's good quality.  

I tried one other dish, the Ma Po Tofu, which wasn't the traditional Cantonese style I'm used to so it was okay and good, but just different than what I'm accustomed to.

The service is good, and friendly.  The decor seems a bit unfinished, but maybe because it's new, but it seems not decorated and simplistic.

The parking is fairly easy, there's street parking in the neighborhood, so prepare to walk, and be aware of the street parking signs, there's a "no parking" as well as "street cleaning" area.
author: Rick S.

description:
Crystal has died from dumpling withdrawals on the Oregon Trail. 

Craving Xiao Long Bao, we headed over to Shanghai Dumpling early last night, no wait to sit down, this location is bigger and cleaner and really, just better than the Balboa St location if you ask me. 

We ordered two baskets of XLB, Pan Fried Pork Buns, Spicy Chive and Pork Dumpling, Bean Sprouts with Garlic Sauce, and Spicy Pork Dumplings. Being *not too* hungry when we got there, I drank tea and listened to my friend vent about the girl who recently cut his heart out and crushed it in front of him with another guy. Poor thing. Then our bean sprouts arrived and I decided to eat a few. 

Slightly crunchy, garlicky goodness overwhelmed me and I had a new take on the situation. As I added garlic pepper sauce to my greens, the advice began to flow. Then came the Pork / Chive Dumplings which are amazing in and of themselves. Spicy, oily, red sauce and lots of garlic and chives. 

One basket of XLB came out and I taught my (unexperienced) friends how to scoop the little steamed dumplings into their spoon, drizzle vinegar sauce over them and take them in all at once. Hot, plump, flavorful, spoonfuls of goodness right there. The steamed pork buns came out next and they were perfect to break up the savory dishes. Slightly sweet exterior was matched with a juicy pork dumpling inside. If I had to do it again (which I plan to) I would probably throw some beef in those. We were definitely on a pork overload and even more so when the second basket of XLB  arrived.

We chatted, sipped tea, and polished off our dinner as we waited for the Fried Egg Doughnuts with Sugar to come out. Pure bliss. We each had one, and my friend desperately wanted to order more to take home, and let me just say that the Chinese are doing it right: one waiter came out with a tray full of fresh, hot doughnuts asking if anyone had ordered them, prompting two tables to ask what those were and then opted for a plate. Nicely done. 

Such a declious dinner and good talk sesh, we all felt content and cleansed of bad juju after we finished. Our meal was superb, service was good, and our bill was $40.40, you just can't go wrong with Shanghai Dumpling King.
author: Crystal C.

description: I think we found our new favorite Chinese Food Restaurant in San Francisco. The soup dumplings were amazing! The honey walnut prawns and honey chilly beef was delicious. And the Shanghai Style Noodles were awesome!!! We'll be back for sure
author: Adrian D.

description: Eh, not really a fan but my friend is. I have to agree with her that the filling inside the dumplings is well seasoned and tastes good BUT the dumplings are so poorly made. There was no soup in the XLB and the roe on top of the pork and crab XLB looked really unappetizing. And the Spicy Wontons? Don't even get me started on those. Oh wait, too late! They were too big, not spicy, and the filling had too much vegetables (not because I don't like veggies but I'm making a point about the lack of authenticity). Chinese food in SF is killing me.
author: Yi Z.

description: Soup in the dumpling are all gone , very disappointed , I expected the dumpling is juicy with little juice inside the dumpling , but too bad everything all gone , food is really taste so so not too impressed, when I told the lady that the dumpling soup all gone , she gave me a bad look with bad attitude , I m scared that she will spit on my food , so I decided just cancel the order , will I go back there ? No thanks with those bad look with attitude Never want to come back again !!
author: love I.

description:
We've always ordered take-out, so can't speak to in-house service.  Every time we've ordered by phone, the service has been courteous and order is ready within 15-20 minutes and it's  accurate! The only con is parking.

The spicy dumplings are more Cantonese-style, so don't expect them to be super spicy, like Sichuan cuisine.  Shanghai dumplings (Xiao Long Baos) taste better eaten in-house (they've usually cooled down by the time we get them home and I miss the scalding soup that pops out at the first bite). To mix things up, we added a sweet and sour chicken dish for the kids in our last order (sans MSG) and it was excellent - crispy bites, lean chicken without being chicken jerky.

This place is definitely dumpling comfort food!
author: M G.

description:
I ordered from Shanghai Dumpling King today and it was very disappointed.  When my order arrived, one of the items, Kung Pao Chicken, came with only chicken in a brown sweet sauce...not what I ordered at all.  There were no veggies and no peanuts and the sauce was horrible.  All I said was no onions/garlic and not too spicy
I asked for them to redo the item, which they did.  When the order arrived, it was again not done properly.  This time there were some veggies, brown sauce again and again, no peanuts.  The woman that answered said that next time I order, I should ask them to put peanuts in it...but the whole point of Kung Pao Chicken is the peanuts! 
I asked them what they were going to do about it and they said they would do nothing. Then the person proceeded to give me a lecture. So I ended the call.
I will not be ordering from them again.  
When you have a limited window in which you can have your dinner, while you're at work, it is difficult to have an order not done properly is frustrating at the least.  
Unfortunately, this ruined my "window of opportunity" for dinner tonight.
author: Ana V.

description:
I had dumpling king delivered to me via Postmates and was very happy with my food. 

The savory soy bean milk never fails to remind me of Taiwan, while the crab dumplings were still wet even though the delivery took 35 min. I hate how some dumplings dry up if you don't have it fresh, but the ones I had was super yummy. The skin was not too thick and the filling was generous. The soup in the Xiao long bao was good too! 

Also had the century egg tofu appetizer which was pretty good though I wish there was more century eggs. 

Very satisfied with my food and would definitely order again!
author: Christina N.

description: Reliable for some things - their soup dumplings and crab-pork (emphasis on the latter) dumplings are yummy and satisfying. Other things we've tried have too much dough.
author: gar l.

description: Inconsistent, a couple of dishes fine, but unfortunately they were the exceptions. If you long for the taste of tired, mediocre, Americanized Chinese food from decades past, you've found your time machine. They even extend the treatment to Shanghai and other dumplings - which were seriously overcooked.The restaurant is WAY  overrated at the current 3 1/2 stars.
author: M W.

description:
This place is my go to take out place though it's best to sit down there and eat since you get much more food and food tastes better when you sit down there in person. Best things to order here are the:
- Pan fried dumplings (good when fresh, small but juicy)
- Pot stickers
- Shanghai noodles
- West lake soup
-  generals chicken
- XLB (lots of meat. less soup, but still good)

This isn't the best Chinese food ever but it doesn't taste bad. it's pretty good, and hits the spot if you want some fresh an fried dumpling / pot stickers.
author: Derrick C.

description:
I'd heard the hype about this place for years, and accordingly, I made the decision to NEVER go there, lest I'd have to wait in a really long line for food that would ultimately disappoint (an experience we've all had with over-hyped restaurants at some point). But that was for the Outer Richmond location. When I found out there was another location in the less trendy Sunnyside district, I figured I'd give it a try. Here's what to know if you decide to do the same: 

* There is never a wait here! Well, maybe once when I was already seated (immediately) on a weekend night, a short queue had begun to build up by the time I was eating. But in general, you and your group can get a table at this location quickly.
* The xiao long bao, the soup dumplings from Shanghai that the restaurant references in its name, are hit or miss. In the handful of times I've been here, I'd say only 1 in every 4 dumplings is filled with enough soup to sip on. With every subsequent visit, I'll admit it has been sort of a bummer to get my hopes up ("THIS time, I'm SURE the dumplings will ALL be oozing with that deliciously savory broth!"). I give it a solid 1 in 4. At best.
* You may be thinking, wait, seriously? How you gonna name yourself after Shanghai dumplings (the King of them, no less) and your XLB is NOT on point?? I can understand that rationale, but also, there are a lot of other really tasty dishes here worth trying that nearly make up for the faux pas of the place's namesake. The spicy dumplings, covered in sesame/peanut sauce, is one. The minced pork noodles are another. Most of the daily specials are usually pretty good, too.
* The prices are extremely reasonable. The last time I feasted here (I left super, duper stuffed), it was still less than $15 per person. 
* I find the service here to be very nice and friendly. For this reason I feel bad not giving them more than 3 stars. But that means I'm totally open to a future update.

All things considered, I enjoy coming to this Shanghai Dumpling King. It's become my go-to when I can't think of anywhere else to eat. At least I know what I'm getting whenever I go (1 in 4, for now).
author: Kate V.

description:
I have a craving that only Shanghai dumpling king can satisfy. 

Don't be fooled by the people loitering outside, sign up for a table! Food comes out quick and tasty. My boyfriend and I will come again and again and again
author: A M.

description: Nothing really outstanding about their food. The Shanghai dumplings were cooked in metal steamers rather than bamboo so the flavor wasn't as good. They were also a bit salty and soggy. The hot and sour soup was overly vinegary. Green onion pancake was dry. The shanghai noodles were ok. The pan fried pork buns were ok. The best item of the meal was the garlic string beans, nice and garlicky flavor. Balboa St. is way better.
author: Ali F.

description: Worst experience ever. I'm not sure if I should blame this on uber eats or the restaurant, but I ordered 2 items at 7:35pm. By the closing time of 9pm my food was still never delivered and it ended up being canceled. Wished this happen before the 90mins I left waiting for it
author: Brittany A.

description: Another Thursday night and I'm getting take out again. Don't do the Yelp order. Call your order for takeout. Waaay faster.
author: brian p.

description:
The food is pretty good here. My grandparents and aunt & uncle love coming here because they swear it's one of the best Xiao Long Baos you can get in the city. I wouldn't really agree on that. Their Xiao Long Baos are good, but there are definitely other places that serve better ones.

The dinner food they serve here is very homey and tasty. I don't know what they're called since my family orders in Chinese, so I'll just go with the description. The fat noodles with beef and some greens, that are chopped up into coins tastes amazing, one of their better dishes. I love eating this one, since it's not a dish my family can make at home.

I love the clay pot rice too. It's a different style from Cantonese clay pot, being that it's Shanghainese, so the meat is thinner sliced and has a different flavor. The bowl is also a huge thin silver pot, versus the thick black one you may usually get at a Chinese restaurant. The rice just has a different flavor to it, probably from the meat. 

I also like the soup because it has a stronger chicken flavor than other places. It's definitely well flavored, probably from the salt. It comes with bok choy, some meat, and the noodle that comes in a knot.

The service is a little frustrating, but what do you expect from a dirty chinese restaurant? They accidentally billed us for 2 of the same dish. Also, another one didn't come out until we asked about it, so it seemed like they forgot about it. Lastly, we brought wine (because my fam loves to drink) but they didn't have wine glasses. So tip, BYOWG. They do have a wine opener though!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
After wandering the Alemany Flea Market with a friend (he's one of those "treasure hunters"), we were cold and hungry. I had seen this place on the way to the market and wanted to try it so we opted to come here for a late lunch. Parking is luck of the draw but tends to be on the difficult side to find. The shop is divey with the sticky tables and chairs and fairly bare decor.

Our order:
Sweet Soy Bean Milk: ($1.50) served hot (Dau Zoeng)
Thai Iced Tea: ($1.75) 
Pan Fried Chives & Meat Pastries: ($5.25) 3pcs
Green Onion Pancake: ($5.25) Chewy, flaky, and savory pan-fried bread (Chong Yao Beng)
Shanghai Steamed Dumpling: ($5.95) 10pc of soup dumpling (Xiao Long Bao - XLB)

The sweet soy bean milk was lightly sweetened in a glass. A bit surprised because I was expecting it in a bowl. I typically like to drink my hot sweet soy bean milk with youtiao (a Chinese cruller) in a bowl but they don't have any! =/

The Pan Fried Chives & Meat Pastries was more of a pan-fried dumpling and not a pastry. The skin was similar to a thin pot-sticker. I personally would've liked it more if it was served with a thick Taiwanese pancake-like pastry instead.

The green onion pancake was very thin and crunchy (like a cracker) unlike the menu's description of the item. It's not what I'm used to so I was very disappointed. I like my green onion pancake with lots of light flaky layers and thicker.

The XLB didn't have too thick of a skin and had just enough soup inside. The skin was also moist enough where it actually didn't stick to the steamer (which is one of my pet peeves). My friend never had it before and completely inhaled the dish and wanted to order more even though we still had several dishes to finish. ^^;;

Service was ok as they cleared our plates when the dishes became empty. Fairly decent food for an ok price. Definitely not the best I've ever tried but filling nevertheless. Want to go back to try a couple other dishes as well if I'm in the area.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Mediocre at best. There is better Chinese food throughout SF and the Bay Area, and there are definitely better dumplings.

We ordered a simple and small dinner- Shanghai Style Meat Wonton Soup Dumplings, Pan Fried Pork Buns, Beef Fillet with Honey Sauce, and Sugar Egg Puffs. The dumplings were hardly soupy, the skin was thick, and the meat wasn't very tasty. The buns were almost inedible to me- the bread was sweet and so was the meat. These buns are amongst my favorite street foods in Shanghai and Taipei, and these were so disappointing. The Honey Beef had very good flavor- a well rounded mix of sweet and savory, but the quality of the meat was very poor. The egg puffs were honestly the highlight of the evening. Like a super eggy popover with sugar on top, they were quite good. I'd come back here only for dessert. 

Too bad :-(
author: Karla R.

description:
Food blah, nothing worth writing about. XLB had no soup, meat was mushy & filled with fat chunks.  Vegetarian goose was cold and probably a few days old.  Shanghai egg roll taste like old greasy oil. And the lady with long hair & glasses, maybe the owner is RUDE with an awful attitude...Never coming back although my family lives up the hill.  Looks like those who don't know good Shanghai food enjoys it.  

Stick to other shanghai locations in the Richmond district, the one on Balboa next to Zephyrs. So much better elsewhere!
author: C L.

description:
Best shanghai dumplings I've had in the city so far!!!

I love both the regular shanghai dumplings and the one with crab meat in it. Really good price for them too!! Thinking about them makes me hungry! Their dumplings are full of soup and never dry, just be careful when you bite into them because you might burn yourself or get soup on yourself!

The shanghai noodles are super bomb too, they're thick and chewy and wonderfully flavored! 

The chicken and the honey beef dish is yummy too but seriously come here for the shanghai dumplings, you won't regret it!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Food 3.5 star
Service 3.5 star

The extra .5 star is specifically for the Shanghai Steam Dumplings and how fast and easy it is to get the food to go here (probably due to location for me).

I recommend ordering the staple piping hot Shanghai Steamed Dumplings dish, it hits the spot (ten pieces for $5.95). Although I like Chinese food and dumplings I am not a Shanghai Steam Dumpling connoisseur.They put small slices of fresh ginger in the soy sauce when you eat at the restaurant but not in the to go soy sauce (fresh ginger makes a difference). The Spicy Deep Fried Chicken Wings are good too. I also recommend the Sugar Egg Puffs for desert (order them early if you don't want to wait because they do take some time to make).  The puffs are good with the warm soybean drink (it is on the menu) but half the time they do not have it. Overall the price is a good value for the portions. It is probably best to come with at least four people so you can try the different dishes. They have a few big tables with a lazy Susan that is good for bigger groups.  The service is fast with no frills. The restaurant and restroom is fairly clean. It is a casual dinning experience. 

I frequent the Monterey Blvd location Shanghai Dumpling King regularly.  I have been here at least 30+ times since they opened and have never had to wait to be seated. No wait is awesome when you just want to get in and out. There is only street parking here but it should not be too hard to find compared to the other location.  They prefer cash for orders smaller than $15 (but willing to take my credit card the few times I showed up without cash). I sometimes will order online and pick up the order.  I find it easier than calling in the order. They do deliver for orders of $30+.

Random observation...

The curtains here are orange. Usually most Chinese restaurants have red curtains or motif because it a good luck color. I wonder if the orange was for the SF Giants or if the orange curtains were a better deal than the red. I am all about good value.

Note: DELIVERY SERVICE STARTS AT 5:30PM UNTIL 9:00PM ONLY (as of 04/25/15)
You can order online at http://shanghaidumplingkingsf.com/
author: Lattie P.

description:
I didn't even have to set foot in restaurant to know the quality of their service. I simply ordered over the phone three orders: Hao gao, Hao gao with chives and Xiao long bao. 

Right when I wanted to finalize my order by confirming that I am ordering 3 things, the representative on the phone yelled at me in frustration and told me that I am only ordering 2 items. 

I repeated patiently to him that I wanted one order of Hao gao and another order of Hao gao with chives and an order of Xiao long bao. He continued to raise his voice and told me that I was wrong. 

It is Christmas Eve 2015 and I felt so stressed for just confirming my order. I politely ended the conversation.

Long story short, I will be taking my business elsewhere.
author: Jackson L.

description: Ordered through Uber eats. Portions are very very small and the food is mediocre at the best. No thanks.
author: Eric C.

description:
That terrifying moment you're gently picking up a Shanghai soup dumpling with your chopsticks, holding your breath so you don't breathe too hard and inadvertently tear the delicate skin housing rich, hot juices before it gets to your mouth... You know what I'm talking about, XLB fans! Worry not, the XLB here are sturdy enough to withstand a few seconds of transportation from bamboo steamer to spoon to mouth, so far with a 100% success (though I still hold my breath every time). 

They're bigger than most XLB I've had, and the wrapper is thicker, too... Which may contribute to its success. The inner broth is fantastic --- complex and well-seasoned --- definitely worth the anxiety and trepidation that prefaces each dumpling. $5.95 gets you 10 of these puppies.

Also tried the "spicy" chicken wings --- fried and doused in a sweet-savory sauce. Prepare to be disappointed if you're anticipating for them to be crispy... or spicy. At $8.95/8 wings, I'll be heading over to San Tung for my next chicken wing craving.

How 'bout the appetizer of "spicy" "bok choy"? FYI: it is neither spicy nor bok choy. Whomp whomp whomp... It's really pickled napa cabbage, and when I say REALLY pickled, I mean the vinegar might burn a hole through your esophagus if it gets stuck midway down. Pair it with some white rice and braised pork belly and it'd probably be a real winner.

As for the pan-fried chives and meat pastries... What a dense and oily mess.
author: Pauline D.

description:
BEST DUMPLING PLACE I've ever been to!!

Things you MUST order:
-Spicy wonton - I don't know of any other place that makes this! The peanut sauce they use is out of this world good!! Not too spicy either.
-Xiao long baos - I'm usually not a fan of these because a lot of restaurants don't cook them right and are really dry. Not at Shanghai Dumpling King though--you really get that "soup" when you bite into it.
-Pan fried pork buns - the bread tastes great! It's not too heavy. Love the meat to bread ratio also. It's just right.
-Sugar egg puffs - the best dessert to end your meal. Sugary, fried goodness.

Service is good! Waiters are nice and attentive. I can't wait to come back to eat more dumplings and try their spicy chicken wings!!! Everything is decently priced, if not cheaper than other dim sum/dumpling restaurants. I love it here!
author: Cristina L.

description: We ordered using Uber Eats twice from this restaurant and both times they were the WORST dumplings I've ever had. I always lower my standards for delivered food because I understand it won't taste as good, but there's no way I could have prepared myself for this atrocity. The only reason why we ordered a second time was because we thought there was no way someone could make dumplings as disgusting as the first time we ordered it. The skin of the dumplings has a way of sticking to your teeth like old glue. If I had bought frozen dumplings from a grocery store, boiled it, went to sleep while it soaked in the pot, then ate it when I woke up, that's how it bloated it would have tasted. Not only this, we ordered the Mango Lassi (although it did taste good), the second time it was only 75% filled (see pic). Not only is the cup already small, if you're going to charge $4 for a drink, at least fill it up.
author: Guorui W.

description:
This place is getting popular.

I like their dumplings, but my favorite is their pan fried one. 

Cucumber salad is really refreshing.

Just a good place for shanghai food in that area.
author: Erica L.

description:
I've only tried their dumplings and xiao long bao is my favorite. Very soupy on the inside and you should be careful cause they squirt when you bite into them. Not good when it's still hot either. The other dumplings I tried were on the dry side and weren't as flavorful and tasty in my opinion. 
Customer service could use some work, but the XLB makes up for it.
author: Renee Y.

description:
Lady waiter opened my coke can and straw wrapper for me, as opposed to the guy waiter (her husband?) who just throws the cans and straws onto the table instead.

+Tip for the service
author: TJ P.

description:
The food doesn't seem the same as the original, but that's not a bad thing. The soup dumplings are a lot meatier and soupier, and seemed to have regained it's consistency in terms of quality. Maybe it's due to the newer kitchen? Overall, so far, I'm liking it here better. One thing that hasn't changed though is the price. Still cheap!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Seeing this spot named in the "new businesses" section on Yelp's cover page, I clicked to joyfully learn that XLB's were less than five minutes from home now.  Stopping by earlier in the week to pick up a takeout menu (they close on Tuesdays so I stopped in Wednesday afternoon), I studied their menu and stopped Thursday for a lunch takeout for the office.
After calling in my order, the waiter told me that my food would be ready in ten minutes.  I ordered two items, finishing one and munching on the other.
The beef stew sai fun (clear cellophane noodles) was my main meal.  They separated the noodles in a small paper box while the broth and meat were in a plastic soup container.  This was just okay as the soup, unlike Milpitas' Darda and Clement St. Taste of Formosa, lacked those deep herb flavors (cinnamon stick or star anise), and the dominant flavor came from sliced red peppers.  The noodles dissolved well in the broth and meshed with the soup well.
The other order was their famed Xiao Lung Bao.  One order is comprised of ten medium sized dumplings with nice 'not-to-thick' skins.  The only disappointment was that the soup content was not very high (not due to broken skins) and the flavor was a bit one dimensional... meaty.  There are ten to each order (held back, eating three).
Their original Balboa Street was in my family's Saturday dinner rotation for many years in the early 2000's.  When the founding owners sold the business and moved to Millbrae, the food quality suffered a bit, making the trek to the Richmond District a little less attractive.  As mentioned in other reviews, they are renovating the Balboa location.  While waiting for my food, I asked the waiter who confirmed that this location is not temporary and will serve as their second permanent location.
The meal was just okay; the staff were all Cantonese speaking which makes one question the authenticity of the Shanghai cuisine here.  Perhaps, they are still working out the opening kinks and hopefully the food quality will kick up as they adjust to their new environs.
author: Mike C.

description: Food was OK, but service seriously sucked. We were seated before the people on either side of us and they were each served 3 platters before we even got one. We ordered 4 dishes and it took 90 minutes of waiting to make it through. Even when the crowd dissipated, we were pretty much ignored. They even gave us the neighboring table's check. Very apathetic service.
author: James R.

description: I LOVE THIS DUMPLING PLACE. To manage expectations - this is not a place you go to for service and ambiance, it's where you go (or order from Uber eats) for delicious, cheap dumplings. They are my favorite offering on Uber eats. The crab pork dumplings are probably my favorite.
author: Kathleen K.

description: Shanghai dumping is no good. Staffs are impolite. Always mess up orders. I don't recommend my friends to come here.
author: Kam Sing L.

description: i had been here for twice. foods and service are very good, super satisfied on both visiting. The price is very reasonable which is chaper than most of the chinese retaurant and the taste are good at the same time. excellent place for lunch.
author: Jaisie Z.

description:
I am very impressed With this place. They are attentive and the non-dumpling plates are just as delicious as the dumplings! 

My husband and I ordered shrimp fried rice, shanghai dumplings, and crab and pork dumplings. All we're delicious and the prices were really low. We will definitely be coming back.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I came here last night because the original location is going through a much needed renovation...this location is much cleaner and more comfortable! And surprisingly, the service is also a lot better than Balboa. This one server/worker guy was all smiles and suggestive selling...which is SO hard to get at any Chinese restaurant [the smile, not the selling]! But my whole family was blown away by his service. Food was also as good as I remembered. The must get Shanghai Soup Dumplings were plump and juicy, spicy beef tendons were flavorful, and the fried donut dessert was just as fluffy and delicious. Potstickers were good, a bit greasy, just as the spicy wontons in a peanut sauce were also deliciously greasy. 

This is basically the same exact thing as the previous location only cleaner! Who doesn't want that?
author: Athena L.

description: It was okay but as soon as we walked in they were rude with us because we had a stroller and they told me next time not to bring it. Even though it was folded and out of the way I won't be back. The food was nothing to brag about and the ambiance was not the best with tons of fly's nats while we were eating.
author: DUN UP B.

description: Mmmm, the sauce from their spicy eggplant had me diving for bread to sop up the juices! Their shanghai style noodles are so good that our family and another family - 2 kids, 2 adults - have to share THREE orders! That's a lot of noodles. We recently discovered their spicy fish, which is both kid friendly and delish. Psst, they do takeaway!
author: Susan L.

description:
Went here on a Friday evening to have dinner with some friends. They won't seat you until your whole party is here. Yelp says that don't take card, but in fact they do. I think you just need to spend more than $20, so it's recommended you bring cash. We ordered 4 dishes and a dessert between 4 people.

First we got the Shanghai steamed dumpling, which was very good. This is the one with the soup in it so be careful when you take the first bite! They're hot! The mapo tofu was good but extremely spicy! I wish I had eaten it over rice! I felt the sauce was both spicy yet sweet. The stir fried noodles Shanghai noodles were somewhat bland. It was just a lot of noodles and barely any vegetables. The pan fried chives and meat pasty was very good. An order comes with three, and you are served a sauce that you can dip it with. 

This place is pretty small. I think the sign says it only seats 59 people. They do have the round tables that seats 10 people. Parking may be difficult to find. Luckily, it was after a certain time and we were able to park in the residential behind the restaurant.
author: Cathie N.

description: Not coming here again, XLB were sweet, and beef brisket noodle soups was not authentic at all, everyone spoke Cantonese and no real shanghainess people here.
author: SJ L.

description:
04/19/2013

What can I say, dumplings are comfort food, and I find it extremely comforting! I love this establishment through and through, and I was certainly excited to visit this new location. I don't know whether this is a temporary location, but regardless, it gives me a reason to venture towards the Sunnyside area. 

I love that this location has more square footage, more seating, and more area to pack hungry guests. My friend and I went in on a Friday pre-evening, and luckily it wasn't busy at the time (6:30ish). An hour into service, it got packed!

Since it was just the two of us, we ordered strategically: (2) bowls of soy bean drink [warm, freshly made, and lightly sweetened]. (2) orders of Shanghai Dumplings [my friend said that the skin was thicker than she is used to, however, I liked the thickness - no explosion of the delicious interior soup], (1) green onion pancake [I love how it is lightly fried and is not greasy at all], and (1) Super Sugar Puff [super airy on the inside, lightly fried to crisp, and sprinkled with cane sugar - a great dessert to an incredible meal]. 

Service was prompt, and our waiter for the night also served my table several occasions at their Balboa St location.

We were also being entertained by the mother and son dual that sat next to us: her child was extremely naughty, but cute [kept poking at their order of dumplings].

I have no objections to returning, and I'm sure they appreciate repeat business.
author: Alex C.

description:
I was surprised to hear that there was a dim sum & dumpling house on Monterey Blvd that was good, so we decided to try it.  The service was amazing...our waiter made a lot of good suggestions, counted the number of dishes to make sure we had enough food, and even made suggestions of vegetables to balance out our meal.

Their xiau long bao (dumplings) were amazing!  You break them open in a soup bowl so to not lose the broth trapped inside.    My kids wanted potstickers, of course, and those were house-made and perfectly seared on one side as they should be.  I wasn't a fan of the won ton soup (broth was a little too brown and salty), but our chow mein noodles were fantastic too -- definitely hand pulled!  We'll definitely be back next time we're in town!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
Same menu as the Balboa street location, but oh wow does the execution fall flat here.

The theme of the night was grease, and even the Shanghai soup dumplings were swimming in shiny oil. I usually love the texture of fried Shanghai noodles, but these were just saturated in fat and already falling apart just minutes from the wok.

Lion's head meatballs tasted like they were mostly spam, and the texture made me think of mechanically separated meats. Weird aftertaste of chemicals too!

Even the egg puffs were underfried and soaking in...yes, you guessed it...oil.
author: Kevin L.

description:
SDK has a new location here in addition to the original one in the Richmond. I've been to the original location a couple times and decided to try the new one since I'm pretty close by. I was never a huge fan of SDK, and it's pretty much the same story here.

Beef Stew Noodle Soup - The broth had a good depth with various spices to highlight the flavor. I could tell that there was some ginger and cloves to give it some layers of complexity. I actually found a piece of dried shrimp in the broth, and that probably helps add some savoriness to the soup. Smart stuff. With the tasty broth, the beef brisket and tendons had good flavor as well, but some pieces could have been more tender. I was not a fan of the noodles though. They were thin like Cantonese egg noodles, but the texture and taste were really odd. The noodles had a strange soft doughiness. It wasn't springy and firm like Cantonese egg noodles or chewy like hand pulled noodles. It was just kind of soft and mushy. I really didn't like that.

XLB - The skin was nice and thin, but it didn't break apart smoothly when I bit into it. The skin had this weird elasticity that made it kind of stretch when I tried to open it up and slurp the broth. It was kind of the same issue I had with Benu's XLB, but at least these are a lot cheaper so it's much more forgivable. Inside, there's a generous amount of pork stuffing, and the broth was pretty much just pure grease. Some people might not appreciate such a heavy handed approach, but it didn't really bother me. What bothered me was the flavor of the broth and pork, which was pretty one dimensional. There wasn't much to balance out the richness and saltiness. It really lacked the aromatic spices like ginger and green onions to cut through the heaviness. The aromatics also give the broth and stuffing a bolder punch of flavor. Without those components, the XLB didn't really stand out.

Stir Fried Green Beans - I thought this was probably the best dish of the night. The green beans had a firm wrinkly exterior while the center was tender and smooth. Garlic, onions, and some fried cured meat stuff added a lot of flavor and crunchy texture to the green beans. It was well seasoned, and the stir frying added that wok hei intensity to the flavor. 

Sugar Coated Chinese Doughnuts (Sah Yong) - They came completely cold and not fresh. I didn't like that the sugar was just lazily dumped on top. It should be evenly coated all around the doughnut. I told a waiter about our lackluster doughnuts, and he had some explanation and comped it for us which was a nice gesture. I still think that if the doughnuts had just been sitting there or if the cook was off, then they shouldn't serve them. In their defense, freshly made Sah Yong isn't that common around here.
