Even venerable Koi Palace can be inconsistent with theirs. I feel like people treat SDK like it's the only place in the city that has good Sah Yong, but I've never had a good one here or at the Richmond location. Am I missing something?

The food hasn't changed with the new location so if you're a fan of SDK, I'm sure you'll still love the food here.
author: Nei N.

description:
ITS CHEAP AND ITS GOOD! 

What can I say about this place! It's Cheap, it's Good, and we had a great experience! These are the rare places in SF , that feels like old SF without over-whelming hipsters that can't cook and judge restaurant food because they feel like they are entitled to everything ! You know who you are! Overprice doesn't mean it's always  good! 

We ordered a lot of dishes and was full, satisfied, and didn't pay for expensive fusion truck food! 

The XLB was good! Because none of them were dry! They all had juice inside !
The spicy wonton was great but I wanted it spicier! That's just me so I added red chili!
The soup ( it was the first item on the soup menu) was really good ! 
The spicy tendon was also good! 
The kids loved the Shanghai noodles, the soup, and of course the sugary EGG PUFFS! 

Half the people in SF! Are great expert critics! Yah ! Whatever ! If you can't cook, don't even write a review! Spoiled sf critics!
author: Wu T.

description: Dumplings up here are way better than in sd! Holy hell im stuffed! Shrimp dumpling and something pancakes of theirs is really good.
author: Tina N.

description:
I have never had such horrible Xiao Long Bao (Little Dragon Wrap aka Shanghai soup dumpling). Got an order delivered from this place and could not finish half of it before tossing it. The Xiao Long Bao's were soggy at the bottom, the meat had gelatinized into a hard lump, and the skin of the bao broke off when you tried to peel it off the wrapper - losing all of the delicious soup in the process.

Also, the spicy wontons which I thought would be like the Taiwanese Red Oil Hot Wontons, ended up being normal large wontons, sitting in gooey, spicy, peanut butter sauce. Not peanut sauce, but literally watery, peanut butter.

Being Shanghainese, I've had the real deal and I've had the commercialized ones from places like Din Tai Fung. The baos here are just so wrong in comparison. Not ordering from this place again.
author: Fiona Y.

description: I ordered delivery from here and I got spicy chive and pork dumplings and beef fried rice. There was so much garlic on my dumplings it was inedible. I could not stomach all of the garlic. The beef fries rice was normal and nothing special. I get better tasting food from the Shanghai on Balboa.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Though it's not exactly in our neighborhood, Shanghai Dumpling King has become our go-to spot for amazing Chinese food.  Eat in and enjoy the lazy Susan rotation, or get it to go.  Either way, you will be pleased.  

Shanghai dumplings, pork dumplings, Ma Po Tofu, Mu Shu pork. You'll see college students, families and the locals enjoying their meal. It appears to be a woman owned restaurant- she'll be working the floor and always telling you about the specials.
author: NJ C.

description:
The Richmond District's loss is Glen Park's gain!!! I was so excited to hear that Shanghai Dumpling King opened up a location in my neighborhood. It had always been a favorite, but the location was inconvenient and it was always crowded! I'm so glad they're renovating the old place but I hope they keep the new spot too when it reopens! 

Some of my favorites:

*Shanghai Steamed Dumpling - the balance of sweet and savory flavor of the soup inside the dumpling is always just right. Bite into it and it'll squirt all over the place so I usually just nibble the top and pour the soup out into the spoon (I have no idea how to make that sentence sound less dirty).

*Green Onion Pancake - Crispy and not too oily.

*Pan Fried Pork Bun - All of the yumminess of a pork bun but FRIED. Kind of doughy though.

*Stir Fried Noodles Shanghai Style - All food should be Shanghai style!

*The fact that you can spend $26 on a satisfying meal for three people (!!!)

My only gripe is they wouldn't do anything for my friend's birthday. How hard is it to stick a candle in an egg puff?
author: Dyanna Q.

description:
Not the best Xiao Long Bao I've ever had but the best in the city. Hit or miss if the soup stays in the bao when it gets to you or if the dough rips as you try to pick it up as gently as you can....!

Other food is standard Chinese food at really reasonable prices. It's easy to let your eyes order more food than your stomach can handle.

No wait at this location the times I've gone and let's keep it that way please :)
author: Timothy L.

description: this is for their delivery through order ahead and caviar. they make the most tasty garlic eggplant i've had in quite a while and their potstickers are delicious and juicy. i am very excited to dine in one day to try their xiao long bao in house. the delivery version ended up being delicious but more like soup with dumplings than soup dumplings!
author: Archana P.

description:
I'd love to give this place 3 & 1/2 stars, but I can't, of course.

Plusses:
1.  They have excellent XLB- xiao long bao, which they are famous for.  For those that do not know, XLB is a tiny soup dumpling, traditionally with pork inside and a bit of broth that oozes or squirts out as you bite into it.  Here, the dumplings (#4-Shanghai Steamed Dumpling) are bigger than normal. The skin is very light and thin, which is desirable for any above-average XLB.  The filling is delectable - moist & tender, and the soup inside is very flavorful.
2.  Their (#34-cucumber salad) is light and crunchy.  It's not overpowering in either saltiness or sweetness.  It also has just the right amount of garlic.  Yum!
3.  (#54-stir fried rice cakes) This dish is really good.  The sauce is nice, without drenching the contents and has some green veggies, which I'd have liked more of.  It has pork too.  My companion noted that some of the noodles stuck to each other didn't have sauce.  Boo.  
A minus for that. ^
Minuses:
1.  (#55-stir fried noodles Shanghai style) I am biased because I don't like this dish to begin with, but gave it a try.  The Chinese ham in it was too salty and there was SO much of it.  And like I said, I'm not partial to it as it is.
2.   Service was pretty slow.  Also, we did not have anyone offer to refill tea or water.  No one even checked if we were needing anything else.  Also, we had to flag down people for the check and a box for take-home.  Yes, I'm aware it's Chinese and service is not expected to be stellar.  But still!

All in all, good food but I'll only go back for XLB and cucumbers if I'm in the area.
author: Natalie C.

description:
Hands down the best Chinese food in the city. Very generous portions of extremely tasty foods, be they dumplings or vegetable dishes or regular main courses. 

You cannot go wrong with the potstickers. Perfectly crispy on the outside and incredible taste in the inside. Spiced just right. The sauces that accompany them are also great. I am also partial to the spicy pork and chive dumplings.

I've also enjoyed the beef and chicken dishes there. None come to mind but none were bad.

The service has also been consistently good. Very pleasant, prompt, and accommodating!

You have a lifelong customer.
author: Patrick O.

description:
A couple of my friends brought me here for the first time a couple weeks ago because they really wanted me to try the xiao long bao, saying it was "killer!"  Boy, they weren't kidding!  We had that along with a few other dishes, but for sure the xiao long bao was my favorite that evening. On a side note, I wouldn't mind having 2 or 3 orders of that alone!

There was plenty of room to walk around in between tables, minimal decor, and a large TV in the back broadcasting variety shows. The dining utensils were absolutely clean, so that's a plus. Service was very good, the waitress was kind and helpful. We didn't feel like we were rushed to order and hurried along to leave, despite being one of the last groups in the restaurant. 

Keeping this review simple, everything was satisfactory.  Will be back again!
author: Stephen R.

description:
Great food, but their captain is a big fucking dick.

He had the fucking nerve to void my coupon because I didn't tell him before hand that I brought a coupon and refused to deduct the check. After fusing about it, he threw my check on the table.
author: Daphne Y.

description:
Very striking name. At first glance, I was expecting a regular Chinese restaurant. Turns out I was half correct. While this place does have many traditional Chinese dishes, their main specialty is steamed food and this also included dumplings. 

We started off with two different types of dumplings, the one with crab and a traditional style dumpling with a pork filling. We also ordered a spicy beef dish and two sides of rice. Like many contemporary Chinese restaurants, they charge by the bowl when it comes to rice so no starch overload here, which can be good and bad.

Both the dumplings were excellent! I haven't had too many soup dumplings in the past so I can't really compare them to any other ones besides the ones that cone in bags for hot pot and the ones over at some buffets. By far, they're the best I've ever had keeping that in mind. The spicy beef was a nice addition to the meal because those dumplings are small and won't fill you up completely.

It's a shame that my family doesn't like just having soup dumplings for dinner, otherwise I'd definitely bring them here. Until they covert their traditional ways, I can always bring friends along with me here.
author: George Z.

description: Ordered takeout on Mothers Day. Showed up after 50 minutes of calling it in and they hadn't even started making my order. Nor did anyone think to call me.
author: Brett R.

description:
Xlb - okay. The skin is a bit too thin. 
Spicy wonton - good. Sauce is peanuty. 
String beans with scrambled eggs - surprising delicious. 
Stir fried rice cakes - yum. The right consistency, not overly gummy.
author: Melinda C.

description: The Shanghai dumplings were unbelievably juicy. We ordered the shrimp and chives dumpling which wasn't as good. Server was hilarious. I would come back again.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
Disappointing order this visit:

Boiled chive dumplings had thick, extremely doughy wrappers that totally obscured the filling. 

Seafood dumpling soup said on menu came w/ 8 dumplings - I think there might have been 4 dumplings max. w/ a few rubbery small shrimp and spinach leaves floating in not even enough broth.  I was pissed b/c this soup was $12 for some reason.  Ridiculous for what they give you.

Minced pork noodles which I remember enjoying before, but this time had totally insufficient pork gravy for the gluey tangle of skinny boiled noodles.  There was barely any sauce to mix into them.

Maybe it was an off night for the kitchen but won't be returning soon.
author: Rose B.

description:
As much as I really want to love this place, it disappoints me that it isn't quite as good as other dumpling places in the city. The food here just doesn't have the same flavor or "punch" to it. 

I think the thing that irks me about this place is the skin of the dumplings. How a restaurant makes their dumpling skins plays a pretty integral role in how great the restaurant is, and here, the skin is always just too thick. It ends up taking away from the actual meat and soup inside because of how much you have to chew on the skin. This is particularly true for the pan fried buns. This is typically my favorite dish to order at Shanghainese restaurants, but here, the skins on them are so incredibly thick and doughy it ends up feeling like you're eating the skin of a pork bun. This isn't how it should be. The noodle dishes are alright (I usually get the Shanghai noodles) in flavor and taste. The portion size could be a bit bigger though.

All in all, this place is a sufficient place to stop by if you're hungry and are craving dumplings. But if given the choice, I would highly recommend going to Dumpling Kitchen or Kingdom of Dumpling instead.
author: Aaron W.

description:
I love this place :D
5 stars service
4.5 stars food
5 stars price

The Xio-Long-Pao?? I am not sure how to spell it, but is the best Ive had in San Francisco. The servers are always nice also. (: 
I love the guys smile and service! 
Keep it up guys ! I love your food!
author: Yumi K.

description:
Pretty straight forward Chinese restaurant, no frills, just food.  We ordered the following:

Beef Stew Noodle Soup:  It was okay.  My friend who judges chinese restaurants by the quality of their beef stew noodle soups, said it was okay.  

Crab and Pork Dumpling:  Good standard soupy dumplings.

Spicy Pork and Chive Dumplings:  This was my favorite.  The flavor inside the soup in the dumpling was sooo yummy!  I wished I could just drink it!

Veggies:  Not memorable.

Sugar Puff Pastries:  Very delicious airy puff donut type dessert with sugar on top.  They said they were famous for them so we ordered 3.  They were good!

The skin of the dumplings are a bit thick compared to what I'm used to at Din Tai Fung (in LA area), but they are generous with the size of their dumplings.  Until I find another go-to dumpling place, I was happy to come here.
author: Helen T.

description: Fantastic dumplings in an unexpected location. I brought my out of town guests here to introduce them to our local flavor...needless to say, they were impressed! HIGHLY recommended.
author: Tyler D.

description: Love this friendly, delicious neighborhood Chinese restaurant. Shanghai dumplings are to die for!
author: Sonia V.

description:
Saw this restaurant on Check Please a few years ago and wanted to eat there ever since.  I just got the opportunity.  

The dumplings were so good!  We had the Shanghai dumplings,  Shanghai noodles, pan fried pork buns, spicy wonton and sweet sugar puff thingy (can't remember the exact names for all these items) . All were excellent.  I can't wait to go back.

Minus one star for service and ambiance.

Parking was also a little iffy. We had to park several blocks away. 

Value was phenominal. We each had a glass of white wine at the end of the meal.  The bill came to $48.00.
author: Margie P.

description: First time eating here! Once again yelp helped me find a great restaurant while driving around in the area.. the food is tastefully fresh and absolutely delicious. The staff was friendly and seriously if you're looking for good authentic food. This is the place to come. I will definitely be coming here again. Best thing I ate would have to be the spicy shrimp dumplings, and the Shanghai noodles! Must haves!!
author: Lila N.

description: Love the XLB and the potstickers.  I order them over and over.  Have cravings every three weeks.  This place is seriously good.  Just went to NYC and went to Bao and it was overhyped compared to this wonderful neighborhood spot.
author: Elizabeth F.

description: It's actually really yummy. Their pork dumplings (xiao long bao) are very tasty, there's just a little too much ginger for my taste. I've learned I'm not a huge fan of chives today as well. Overall I enjoyed this place a lot. The workers were nice and it wasn't too crowded. Their thai iced tea is excellent, just very sweet. Parking is not the easiest, but there is parking on the adjacent residential streets.
author: Michelle Y.

description: the peanut sauced dumplings were bizarre and really overpoweringly peanuty. Had the pan fried pork buns, the shrimp dumplings, the xiao long bao, and maybe one or two other things...they were all just ok. nothing wowed me and quite frankly some of it was a bit odd/off tasting. I dont think Ill go back. only thing that was memorable was the rice cake stirfry
author: Tara B.

description:
WOW...love this place! Had the most delicious crab dumplings that have the soup in it (sorry, I don't know what it's formally called). Very delicious and with so much flavor. I totally recommend getting these! 

I was also very impressed with their Fish Fillet with pepper salt. The fish fillet was fried in this tempura batter that was well seasoned with the pepper salt. Every time I took a bite I always had this light and airy crunch, which is what you would similarly get from anything beer-battered, while the meat in the inside was perfectly cooked and as soft as tofu. That's the thing that amazes me with the fish fillet dishes from Chinese restaurants...they always cook the fish in such a way that it comes out tender, juicy, and absolutely decadent. I was definitely impressed with this dish. 

Other things I tried was the sweet soy milk, the mapo tofu, onion pancake, and the sugar donut. The sweet soy milk was absolutely delicious. I chose to have it warm and it totally soothed my soul :). Now, their SUGAR DONUT was TO DIE FOR! I hear they come out randomly whenever they make them and serve them out fresh and THAT'S IT. Luckily, they came out when I was there! It came out fresh outta the oven and sprinkled with like a teaspoon of sugar. As I tore it apart, it actually was a hollow donut, but SO FLUFFY. It was like an empty cream puff donut. But, oh wow...the inside was glimmering with shine of freshly baked egg and this soft and moist consistency throughout, unlike a cream puff which has a more rough and tough exterior. It was so good, I actually ate two! The sweetness definitely comes from the sugar, but it's the texture that you just fall in love with. Whatever you do, DON'T HESITATE to pass these up. When you see them being served, get them because that may probably be your only chance. As for the mapo tofu and onion pancake, these were both OK. The mapo tofu was good, but I wasn't too impressed with it. The onion pancake was not impressive either. I didn't like how dry and crispy the pancake was, and I was assuming it was going to be flakey and moist. 

I love Chinese food and this place rocks!!! Definitely a go-to place to me!
author: Michelle S.

description:
3.5 stars really. No wait, lots of big tables for groups and the food is pretty decent. There's plenty of parking in this area. Our family has already come back twice. Both times we were able to get a table of 8. 

Their soups and noodles are solid. Dumplings are not great and it was overcooked the last time we went. Xiao long boa is okay. Taraval shops are way better, but this is so easy to get to and their veggies were not as overly salty.
author: Winny F.

description: I have been here for more than 5 times and like the more fresh, and light seasoning they have. but the portion has gone down sooo much the last time I went. service is good and flavor is still good tho.  so actually 3.8 stars.
author: Shuting Z.

description: This place has the best beef chow fun I've ever tasted. Snow pea leaves are fresh and flavorful. Sizzling rice soup was amazballs! The best potstickers ever! I'd recommend this place to anyone who wants some home cooked Chinese food.
author: E B.

description: Honestly the most overwhelming and negative place Ive been to. As soon as you walk in you can feel the tension. Waiters running dripping food (and boiling water) i would definitely not recommend this place to anyone. The food is good but the service and all ambiance makes it hard to enjoy your food.
author: Daniel M.

description: The honey beef and their dumplings are good! The food is fairly priced, service is fast, and the staff is so friendly.  Portions are pretty big.
author: Sheila G.

description:
I like the experience here, and my two American friends had good time as well. I like they put more authentic Shanghainese food and Americanized Chinese food in the same menu. No one feels got excluded. Since I am not originated from Shanghai area, I can't really tell how authentic the food is. However, I like the taste here. My MSG-sensitive partner didn't feel sick and liked the food too. That is the most important thing for me.

The decoration can be better though. I don't really think they put as much effort on the environment as in their food.
author: George C.

description:
Veggie dumplings, delectable soft skin...hate when rubbery gummy...stuffing fresh, but better with more zest...yes, add pinch of cilantro.

Salt & pepper fish, even better...crisp coating...tender fresh fillet...salt & pepper just right.

Monsieur waiter, attentive...friendly, eager smile.

Price reasonable...no status fatus fees inflatus. 

 flat screen...Costa Rica by Greece on penalties!

Will return...
author: Saul M.

description: larger location...tables plenty...easier parking...cheap prices...late dinner...sizzling rice soup large, hot and sizzling...tasty soothing clean broth...spicy tendons deliciously large mound...good numbing heat...razor thin slivers...great chew...steaming hot soup dumplings bursting with flavor...thin skin and delicate, but not falling apart...meal for two with three-item order $twenty-three total...
author: Hen A.

description: Bring a fork if you can't use chopsticks! There isn't a single fork in that building. Food was ok if you have a pallet for mildly flavored Chinese food. We ordered the egg foo young which was a little too salty, the general tsos chicken which was good but salty, and the potstickers which were bland. The place was clean which is a plus and the seating a little tight. However the waiters are slow in making their rounds.
author: Dennis O.

description: Too bad I can't give a 4 star review. We like the place... good food and friendly people.  But there's a REALLY annoying chime that rings constantly for the kitchen ordering system. In the dining room it's like being inside a kindergartner's video game.  So, good food, and pretty good atmosphere polluted by annoying electronic chimes.  Too bad.  We have to find a new place for great dumplings.
author: Drew C.

description:
From the lower ratings, seems like cleanliness or lack of, seems to be an issue here. 
My wife noticed SDK as we drove up Monterey. We were only momentarily ecstatic until we remembered an incident in their old location, where we found a dead cockroach in a plate of pig ears. 
When we pointed out the cockroach to a staff member, he simply said, "must
have come from the vegetables..."
author: Geordie E.

description:
5 stars when it's good, 3.5 stars when it's off a bit. 

I live close and usually come here once a week. For the most part, the food is great. Occasionally they'll have an off day when the food doesn't taste like it normally does, but I'll just chalk that up different cooks. 

The dumplings are the best thing I've had here - particularly the XLB and spicy wonton. Those two are in consistent rotation. We'll usually order another dumpling along with these two but the third one is never quite as good as these two. 

The braised string beans are the best side dish we've had, but nothing we've ordered has been bad. 

Don't come here for ambiance and terrific service, cause you'll be let down. Come here for good, cheap food and you'll leave happy.
author: Jake B.

description:
Went here with my girlfriend, sister, and her boyfriend. Seating here around 5pm is pretty good. Had an order of the XLB, a spicy dumpling, and a vegetarian dumpling with the green onion pancake and some noodles. I must say, the dumplings here are great. All of them were really good. The XLB was pretty surprising to me. Never had soup inside of a dumpling. These wrappers did not break off like some of the places you get dumplings. The food here is also pretty cheap. We were filled for less then $10/person. 4 stars because service here could be better. I understand being busy and phone orders but they could have been more courteous with the sauce. If they left it at the table it would have been better than asking every few minutes.

Must try? YES.
Try again? Of course.
author: Thomas N.

description: Good food, but horrible service. One of my order never made it to my table and I couldn't get any service to check on my food. I understand the nature of service in Asian restaurant, unfortunately, I experience the worse here. I can see how business was good and the staff was busy throughout my time being there, but I'm still a paying customer who at least must be tended. I can't see myself coming back again especially since I don't think it will be difficult to find other restaurants that serve Xiao Long Bao in San Francisco.
author: Annie A.

description:
The XLB (Soup Dumplings) are to die for.  I get off the freeway and take them home to San Jose and they're still good an hour later.  Also great are the Egg Puffs and Green Onion Pancakes.  Prices are VERY good.  Parking is pretty tough though.
Best XLB in Northern CA.  They also have a location on Balboa St, SF.
author: Ed D.

description:
I've a regular here, and practically order 2-3 times a month with them, it be either To-Go or dine in! I always order my two favorites the Shanghai Pork Dumplings or Spicy Wonton.

They probably recognize me every time I go, but this place is not only super good, but the prices are great! Every shanghai dumpling place I try will never make me feel as good as when I eat from here.

I highly recommend you try this place, as for parking good luck finding one on the streets! $20 minimum for credit cards btw.
author: Alex D.

description:
I just want to say that this restaurant doesn't know what they are doing.
yeah, maybe a few dishes here and there is Shanghai but over 50% were not.
I can't even find the shanghai sweet and sour pork rib in their menu.
worst off all, they put 3 cup chicken (which is a Taiwanese dish) they came in completely wrong -no garlic, basil or ginger which is what's usually in this dish. instead they put american onion and scallion. wtf?
don't put a dish in the menu is you don't know what you are doing.
I complaint to the restaurant but of course complaint to this type of low end chinese restaurant is no use.
whatever! won't be coming here again.
author: Rina C.

description: My friend and I came here because I really want to try San Francisco's soup dumplings. We ordered pork soup dumplings, rice cakes, pea shoots, and sheng jian bao. I liked the pea shoots the best. I didn't think the dumplings were that great, I had better in New York City, but the pea shoots were really tasty. The sheng jian bao were all right, but I had better as well. The rice cakes were a bit gelled. But I thought the service was really efficient!
author: Shirley X.

description:
Came here on a monday with some friends and the place was not packed but it looks like they do usually have a wait since there was a wait list sign up sheet on the front table. 

We ordered an order of xlbs, the green onion pancake, the pan fried dumplings, some spinach veggies dish along with an order of the veggie dumplings. 

All the food came out super quick and everything was really good. The xlbs had just the right amount of soup in them. The only thing I was a little disappointed in was the green onion pancake. It didn't have the right consistency and enough of the green onion pancake flavor I was used to and craved.

But the dinner was soo cheap. Only $40 for the 4 of us and we were all stuffed! Will be coming back here more when I have an xlb craving and I don't want to go to far away from my hood!
author: Christine W.

description: Best dumplings in the city and anywhere I've been. Soup dumplings, pork and chive dumplings, and pea shoots are my favorites. Love this place!
author: Rachel W.

description: Too greasy for my taste and small portions and the food does not come out quick only the veggie platters
author: Dave A.

description:
I probably won't come back.

The shanghai dumplings were just okay.  Half of them broke when we lifted off the steamer, and the juice fell out.  The shrimp and chive spicy dumplings were much superior.  

Shanghai stir fried noodle was nothing special, even though the waitress touted it as one of their signature dishes.  Would not order again.  

We also got a veggie goose appetizer that was clearly recently thawed from the freezer because it still had crunchy ice crystals.
author: T Y.

description:
I don't understand why people hate on Shanghai Dumpling. It's a great place. Been meaning to try it for a while since it's pretty close to where I live. It did not disappoint 

Xlb- 10 for 5.50. What a great deal. Very good. Like a true batch some were entrenched with broth whereas some weren't. Flavorful, large portions of pork.

Garlic Eggplant- usually not hard to botch this, and they didn't.

Spicy wings- heavily battered and crispy, just the way I like.

Great value, simple Chinese restaurant like the ones I used to frequent with family when I was a kid.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Bottom line: pretty terrible "Shanghainese" food.

Two of us came here on a Sunday evening. I was craving for some light Chinese food. The restaurant was quite empty when we were there. 

We ordered Shanghai steamed dumplings (xiao long bao), braised beef in an iron pot, vegetable rice (cai fan), and some stir-fried green leave vegetable with bean curd. Their xiao long bao was pretty sad for a place that's supposed to specialize in Shanghai dumplings. I suspect they made their xiao long bao with those wonton skins bought from supermarkets instead of making their own dumpling skin (the xiao long bao skin tasted very much like rubber). And when the dumplings were served, almost all them them had broken skins which means the precious soup inside the dumplings all leaked. Then the dipping sauce that came with xiao long bao contained coarsely diced ginger instead of fine Julienned ginger, which was a big red light for me.

The vegetable rice was alright, slightly on the greasy side. Stirred fright vegetables with bean curd was very bland. I give them an extra star for the braised beef, which was probably the highlight of our dinner.

Afterwards I talked to some Shanghainese friends of mine about our dinner experience, and it turned out they all think this place (and its two other sister restaurants with the same name in the bay area) was pretty crappy too.
author: Christine C.

description:
My two buddies and I went here for an early lunch yesterday (Sunday). It was predetermined the night before when we were at our third bar and like 12 drinks deep that we were going to have soup dumplings the next day for lunch. We got there right when it opened so we were seated right away. 

Atmosphere:

Your typical family owned, semi hole-in-the-wall kind of place. Decor is blah. But keep in mind that this is just the temporary location until their original one is done remodeling. So don't put too much emphasis on the look of this place. 

Food: 

Pretty good! We got three orders of the Shanghai Steamed Dumplings, one order of the Pan Fried Pork Bun, Braised String Beans and Shanghai Style Soup. It was all pretty good. The steamed dumplings (soup dumplings) weren't bad. The first batch we got was pretty weak - most of the dumplings were flat so they lacked the steaming hot delicious soup inside. The second and third batches were rad. I think my favorite thing here were the Braised Strings Beans. SO GOOD! They top it of with a ton of sauteed garlic and onions - flavor burst for sure!

Service:

Not great, not bad. Just your typical family owned Chinese restaurant. If you're Chinese, like I am, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Ha!

If you're in the mood for soup dumplings, check this place out. You won't be disappointed but at the same time, you won't be blown away. If you've ever had the soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung in SoCal (Arcadia) or even in Taipei, Taiwan then you've had the best - every other place comes second!!!
author: Bruce C.

description: I'm a big fan of Shanghai cuisine.  Especially xiao long bao.  And when I saw that this place sold it for just under $7, I had to check it out.  When I arrived it was around 4:30 pm on a Sunday.  Naturally it was pretty empty but the decor seemed nice enough for a hole in the wall place like this.  The tea was very good and the waiter was polite.  I waited a little longer for my food than most other places I've been but that wasn't terribly upsetting.  The xiao long bao was very soupy, which is good in my opinion.  The broth, however, was a bit too sweet for me and the dough was a little too sticky.  And unfortunately, I didn't care for their vinegar ginger sauce. I also tried the spicy wontons and they were quite good.  Everything was exceptionally average.  But you can't beat the price I suppose.
author: Kyle T.

description: I got the soy braised pork rump and it had hairs in it. Pig hairs. Attached to my meal. From a pig.
author: David B.

description:
I loved the Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa in the Richmond district. Was super excited to find out the new location; it's walking distance from where I stay! 

I don't think people fully understand that this restaurants specialty are their XLB, dumplings and Shanghai dishes. If you're looking for regular, common Chinese dishes, I suggest going right across the street.

Service is good and you're looking for great Xiao Long Boas that will leave you 100% satisfied, this is the place to go.
author: Alice T.

description:
Positives
- Convenient -- this location is on Monterey Blvd across from Safeway
- Parking is plentiful and non-metered
- Waitstaff speaks both English and Cantonese
- Average wait time is much less - this place is not too busy and the restaurant can accomodate up to 50 (or so says the signage, although I'm sure they can pack more folks in w/ the extra chairs stacked on the side of the wall)
- Credit card is accepted (although there's a minimum $20 charge)
- Pricing is the same or thereabouts with the Balboa location
- I would have to say the only good thing I had here was the green onion pancake.
- Orders easily taken and food comes quick -- service is not bad at all!

Highlights (or Lowlights)
- XLB were quite large, soupy, and a little undercooked(pink?).
- Pan fried bao was crispy on the side facing the pan but the other side was mushy to the point of.. perhaps they put a little too much water in the pan.
- The soy milk was the consistency and look of vitasoy if you can imagine. Depending on if you get the salty or sweet one, they both look the same -- this is not what I remember the one at the other place to taste like -- I'm sorely disappointed. 

Maybe my memory of the other Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa set my expectations really high, but I'm sorry SDK#2, I'll be taking the time to drive out to Balboa & 30smth to get my fix.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Maybe it's because I'm a white guy, but I disagree with a lot of the negative reviews here. I'm a pretty picky eater when it comes to excellent quality, and I thought this place was pretty good. I notice a lot of Asian restaurants get dinged if the recipes are the slightest bit different than the way the reviewer's grandmother made it, even if it's good. I think that's the case here. Food is really good. 

For example, we had the Lion's Head. I know it's supposed to be cooked with cabbage,  as the cabbage is the lion's mane. This one used some other green leafy vegetable, but it was oh so good!
author: Bib G.

description: Terrible service even no one except our table. They don't serve soy bean milk here!!! So disappointed! No way I m coming again.
author: K W.

description:
1) if you're coming here for Chinese food you ("you" meaning the person who typically would get) get at say, Panda Express (broccoli beef and sweet sour bullish) then you're coming to the wrong place. My rant is plain and simple: don't go to a shanghainese restaurant expecting Chinese/chinese American style fast food 

2) xlb, you rock my world 

3) chicken wings, I love you 

4) rice cake of my eye, I adore you
author: Jac T.

description:
Great spot for xiao long bao in San Francisco. Don't come here expecting great service. I've been here three times already and am always seated by disgruntled diners. Talk about a buzz kill. It's a very busy Chinese restaurant--don't expect much. 

The food is amazing for the price it's at. My recommendations: garlic string beans, soup dumplings, lion's head, and egg puffs. 

Always leave room for the egg puffs. They're doused in white sugar, but they are delightful.
author: Patricia Q.

description: Food was pretty good; service was friendly and fast (although it was 2pm on a weekday, so the restaurant was fairly empty). We took the waitress up on her recommendation of the wings and were not disappointed. Spicy wontons were our favorites. Two of us were heartily stuffed for ~$30. Would eat again!
author: Namita D.

description: Dumplings are good.  Noodles could be better.
author: Mar M.

description: I have been on a dumpling craze lately, ever since I got back from NY. Prosperity Dumplings in NY has got to be the best dumplings I have ever eaten, check them out if you are ever in NY! Anyways, I give Shanghai Dumpling King 3 stars because the prices were affordable, they have a huge variety of dishes to choose from and because the food was okay for the most part. I docked down two stars only because the waiter who was taking our order kept insisting we try other things instead of what we were trying to order. We did took her advice on the pan fried BBQ pork buns and I hate to say that was a bad idea. It wasn't to my liking, would have rather ordered the original pan fried buns.
author: Kristy V.

description:
Finally, a solid Chinese restaurant in the neighborhood. Good, cheap Chinese food that satisfies every craving. The shanghai steamed dumplings were delicious. Minced pork noodles are legit. 

The best part is that they're RIGHT DOWN THE BLOCK from the house! And the deliver! 5 stars for being convenient and cheap with awesome service.
author: Kimmy D.

description:
I'd never been to their previous incarnation, but had heard mostly good things. Didn't realize they were related at first, but I'd seen them when driving along Monterey many times. 

The XLB were huge and the skin thick. We also ordered the Spicy Pork and Chive Dumpling. Again, thick skins. Good flavoring, but if you decide to wait longer than the first few minutes upon arrival to eat them, they're just not as good.

Ordered my staples at these types of restaurants - rice cakes and Shanghai thick cut noodles. The noodles were terrible, mushy. We barely made a dent in the plate. The rice cakes were good enough to take for lunch the next day.

Also ordered veggies - pea shoots. Good enough to take home for lunch also! 

Overall, the people seemed nice here. There's a lot going on with the menu here, so maybe the other items are a hit. For now, I need to rewrite my XLB experience by going somewhere else!
author: Tinna H.

description: Had a ROCK in my steamed pork and veggie dumpling. Are you kidding me?! ROCKS?! I don't even think a review is even worth my time if there's rocks in my food.  What if I chipped my tooth or choked. Hell no.
author: Donna A.

description: I crave the Shangai Dumplings probably more than any other normal person should. They are amazing! This place is so convenient when I'm at my boyfriends house that I always want to eat there or order out. The wonton soup is great also! Definitely recommend giving them a try.
author: Casey L.

description: I like this spot for the soup dumplings !! they are 10 for 6$ and super good ... nice mom and pa type restaurant.
author: Micah W.

description: Best Glazed Walnut Prawns I have ever had.
author: Peter L.

description: I have to say the dumplings here are good! But I felt iffy about the vegetarian one because the consistency threw me off. The meat dumplings though are really good.
author: Dominique S.

description:
This is the fourth change of ownership of this restaurant space since I've been keeping track. It's now a second branch location of a popular place, the first one being in the Outer Richmond on Balboa Street which seems to always have people waiting for a table when I drive by.

I tried the XLB and it was great, 10 pieces for $5.95 (I think).  It definitely seems to justify the fact that I see people for tables at the other location.  I haven't seen lines yet here but it could be that this space is bigger.  The hot and sour soup was excellent too and good portion for the price charged.

The male server who greeted me when I came in was very friendly.  As for one of the other stuff, a lady who (the way she dresses) seem to be both the cashier and helps with servicing, I had a bad impression of her at frist because she seemed stuck-up but later that behavior improved a bit.  Still she could be better.

This will definitely be a new hangout spot when I have craving for the XLB and hot and sour soup combination, especially since this is along my commute route.
author: H K.

description:
Positives: Quick friendly service, and food came out very quick.

Negatives: The food I ordered was the very generic was quite tasteless. Egg roll that came with my order was soft and tasted of oil. Rice seemed like it was 3 days old. Food was nothing special. The broccoli and beef that I ordered literally tasted of the "supermarket chinese food" variety--you know, the chinese food at the supermaket that are on heating trays and you just scoop what you want you want into the box. Also the kung pao chicken was greasier than Walmart parking lot.

Overall, it's bad chinese food that is quite expensive. Personally, there are so many better options around the city for chinese. Please don't waste your time and money here.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Super cheap and filling dumplings! The dumpling wrappers are thick, but I enjoy thicker-skinned dumplings (versus dumplings with skins that fall apart as soon as you bit into them).

I think they also gave us little home made cookies when we ordered, which were really good! There was one cookie, I think it was a dark chocolate chip with sea salt? That was yummmmmyyy!

Their shrimp fried rice should also be a staple when you order from here :)
author: Christina C.

description:
Last Saturday the crew and I decided we needed dumplings for lunch, so we headed up the peninsula to SDK, and we were shocked to see it closed....what?!

After reading the sign, we proceeded to this new location and saw the "cash only" sign, sigh...  After visiting the Safeway across the street (which doesn't have an ATM, so you actually have to buy something from them to get cash...grrrrr!) we sat down for a good meal.  We ordered too much...!

The dumplings were great as usual, but because I wasn't all that hungry to begin with, I was viewing everything with a little harsher criticism than normal.  I thought the skins were a little thicker than normal; not a big deal, but it seemed to mesh with what we felt about the other items we ordered.  

We got the Shanghai Style Crispy Salt Pan Cake and the Pan Fried Chives and Meat Pastries; both were good, but they had the  same issue- while some pieces were cooked perfectly, most had an internal layer of undercooked goo that wasn't really pleasant.  Not sure what to think- had we just ignored this in the past?  Hard to say.

The Sugar Egg Puffs were AWESOME as usual!

I'm sure we'll be back, but we'll be more careful about what we order (maybe it's time to try other things!)
author: Dave S.

description:
I love their dumplings!! The spicy chive and the xlb are excellent every time. 
I find the service at this location to be far better than the original. Can't go wrong with the pea shoots as well. I come to this place often
author: Wendy K.

description:
I've been here before and thought it was mediocre. Ive been through my fair share of shanghai dumpling places to give a fair review... i walked in and there was a lady who was on the phone whose screaming and yelling. we waited for a few moments before she spotted us and then angrily directed one of her staff (i assume she is the owner) to get us seated. 

The wait wasn't long, granted there were only three tables occupied in there, and that was the only good thing.

First off, eating soup dumplings require both ginger and vinegar. But what they provided us were these few small pieces of ginger, (more like 1/5 the size of an m&m) that was dipped in an inch of vinegar. it got so bad that my dad and i made a competition out of who could get the first piece of vinegar into their dumpling...no one won.

the soup dumplings were terrible. The dumplings that were made to have soup in them...HAD NO SOUP. all of them were poked through and all the soup was gone...so the dough ended up being very dry and sticky. Not one of them had the SOUP in the soup dumplings, which is the most important part of any xiao long bao. The meat was falling apart inside the dumpling that was mostly fat by the way. It  tasted really frozen. and i know enough that shanghai dumplings are supposed to be frozen because thats how you can get the congealed soup inside a closed dumpling. but me and my dad, right off the bat, knew that it was frozen for a very long time.

the shanghai noodles had a bitter aftertaste and its probably from th spinach or the cabbage. They doused so much soy sauce into the dish that it was hard to enjoy. this is considerably one of the hardest dishes to make because its so simple and restaurants seem to overcomplicate it..and I've yet to find a place that makes it easy to eat.. this restaurant tried o pack it with so much flavor that it became overwhelming.

and next..the fried dumplings...

oh gosh. my first bite was weird..for some reason, i just knew that the meat was possibly spoiled. it had such a weird aftertaste that i felt compelled to take another bite...my dad and i looked at each other and then finished off the dumpling..and then ate another. 

it was just so weird... my dad didn't think it was spoiled and insisted that it was just how it was suppose to taste so we finished off the plate. but i had a gut feeling that it really was a weird taste for a dumpling.

BAD DECISION.

on the way home, about ten minutes after the meal, i get hit with the biggest pains in my stomach. it was torture. i don't know if its was the spoiled food or dirty water from the tea or the tap water they gave me but i was sure that this was the restaurant that did this. i didn't eat breakfast that day and it had been like 15 hours of no food in my system until i ate here. 

i think its safe to say that I will never come here to eat again. food that isn't up to par, flavor isn't good, and o-kay service is one thing, but for food to not be clean?? for there to possibly be a dirty kitchen in the back of the place is another thing that is just BAD!

you do realize that you guys are putting food into people's mouths?? 

ABSOLTELY TERRIBLE. perhaps its a case-by-case thing and I'm the only one dealing with this. but my dad is now having stomach aches and diarrhea as well. 

this restaurant is terrible and i urge you all to go the the other dumpling store that is right across from the street. their shanghai dumplings are amazing and they're BOGO. much better than this place.

don't ever come here.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
It sorta weird how to give a rating for this place. One part of me hated it because the XLB was a bit sweet and weren't that soupy.

That said, holy crap, some of the other dumplings like the spicy pork wontons and pan fried meat pasties were incredible. They were succulent and tasted amazing (the sort of amazing that puts a silly smile on your face). I plan on going back to try some of the other recommendations. I have a sneaky feeling they have lots of goodies.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Sigh. I hate to write another bad review back to back. But I'll try to be positive and offer the good along with the bad. So lets get this baby started.

The Good:
I've been to their original location on Balboa many many times and I have always appreciated their food.  The cleanliness of the restaurant, not so much but I over looked it.  As long as they didn't sit me by the restrooms, I was ok. I am in love with Shanghai Soup dumplings. Coming from NYC where we have Joe's Shanghai and Nan Xiang Dumpling House (delish) I am always in the quest for shanghai soup dumplings.  This resto (along with a few unnamed others that I have found) offer me a good choice for when the soup dumpling hunger pangs strike.  The food is of decent to good quality. Soup dumpling can be hit or miss depending on the visit.  A good restaurant should always have high quality food anytime you visit. That's what sets it apart from its competitors. Lions head meatballs. Yummy! I like the one with the gravy. They have a soup one but I've never tried it.

This bad review is for their new relocated restaurant on Monterey Blvd. Visit 4/28/13 12:15pm
The Bad:
OMG. Cleanliness is such issue with this place.  I don't care myself since I grew up in NYC and always eat at a wide variety of establishments.  I eat at food trucks, food stalls, I visit food market in asia. I don't care and i understand not everyone is super clean. I get it. But my dining companion was really irritated with their unsanitary habits that it ruined his dining experience.

Examples from my notes:
1) tables were wipes down with a damp rag (dirty) then left to air dry while still wet. The dirty rag was then put into a pile to be reused by the other wait staff to wipe down other patrons tables. This dirty pile was never washed nor taken away to washed.
2) the servers who used their hand to pick up the dirty wet rag and wipe the tables did not wash or disinfect their hands afterwards and continued to handle customers dishes, utensils, drinks, food, and money.
3) utensils and napkins had food particles remaining on surfaces.
4) "Jerry" (employee/boss) would shake customers hands on 3 separate occasions and proceed to work handling items mentioned above without hand washing/disinfecting.
5) Dining companion could not find health inspection score card posted conspicuously on the premises within customers view.

So you take this review for what it is. Would I still eat here? Of course! I'm not anal about this stuff. Can I recommend them to my friends and family? Only to those who aren't squeamish about cleanliness.

The service is as attentive as it should be for a chinese establishment (brief and concise) The food tastes decent. Just set your expectations at the right level and you will have a good foodie time.
author: Eric T.

description: Gratifying dimsum! Started off with hot and sour soup and it was so tasty and flavorful would clear your nostrils! Dumplings worth trying are the Hung Zhou Crab & Pork Steamed Dumpling, Vegetable & Pork Steamed Dumpling and the Spicy Wontons were tasty and  appetizing! Cheap and quick meal that is very satisfying with about 8 to 10 pieces per order.  Very good!
author: Maria M.

description:
I've been to this location twice in the past as I have a friend who keeps raving about the crab & pork dumplings and I didn't remember anything bad.
I ordered the Shanghai Dumpling, Crab & Pork Dumpling, Pan Fried Pork Buns, and Spicy Chicken Wings.
The Pan Fried Pork buns was tossed on a plate, dropped onto our table and it looked wet..... Well boy was I wrong to give them the benefit of the doubt... 
I decided to break it apart, I just see this small blob of pink 'meat' and gloop.
I take a bite anyway because it doesn't look raw at least.
The outside of the bun was slimey, not that it was raw, just plain slime. Then this overwhelming aftertaste came through; this bun was going to kill me and if I keep eating more of them, I don't want to imagine. I can only describe it as when you know your food's gone bad taste/smell.
The XLB people rave about, I had 1/10 with actual soup within.
The skin on these dumplings are pretty thick too, so where the heck did the soup go?
The crab & pork dumpling is the biggest portion I've seen, it's aite.
The chicken wings...it tasted like sauce from a bottle. At some point, I was pushing the sauce off my lightly seared chicken (where is my deep fried battered crispy wings?!) and this jelly chunk slid off.
$40 down and I'm so sad.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Parking is definitely easier to find in this hood than its original balboa street location. Same restaurant waiters and owners, and low prices.

XLB's are good and the sugar creme puff is good. I like the noodle dishes as well. Hopefully they dont move out of this location.
author: Joiera C.

description:
This location of the Shanghai Dumpling King makes a decent shanghai dumpling ... but not much else.

Ive eaten here several times and have tried a few different things on their menu.  Everything seems to come out super greasy, and they skimp on their meats.  Their chef here is not on par with their chef at Balboa location.  I always come here with high expectations from memories of great food, but leave disappointed.
author: Yeeman N.

description:
Fabulous Food!
The dumplings are amazing. While I love the Shanghai Dumplings, my favorites are the Spicy Chive Dumplings. They literally melt in your mouth. We ordered both dumplings (and you get 10 with each order) and also the spicy eggplant. The two of us were stuffed for under $25 including tip and the food is so tasty!
author: Debbie B.

description:
World's best green beans. Seriously, I've never had green beans better than at Shanghai Dumpling King. And I'm so psyched that it's in my parents' neighborhood now!

The first time I experienced the awesomeness of this place was many years ago with a friend at the Balboa location and we had the green beans and soup dumplings for lunch and stuffed ourselves for under $10 per person. I've been back many times since with various friends and family, and the food has been consistently good (and consistently cheap!). My mom's favorites are the spicy wontons. My dad likes the traditional soup dumplings, and I am a sucker for those green beans. They are not too crunchy or too soft, and incredibly flavorful. I could live off of them and probably would if I still lived in close proximity to my parents.
author: Whitney G.

description:
Very disappointed.  The xiao long bao was terrible.  Thick wrappers, lacks flavours. Felt like I was eating balls of unseasoned ground pork fat.  The black vinegar did not have any of the fragrant aromas and it tasted very sweet.  There was hardly any ginger in the vinegar.

I can't believe this place has anything to do with the restaurant on Balboa street.  No comparison.
author: TopCat W.

description:
This spot is located conveniently right on the corner, sadly not much parking on the main street but I was able to find parking right behind it very fast. Restaurant has a very weird decor thing going on. Everything looks very 1980's. Everything is old. Weird drapes. But they added these floral lanterns here and there. Just plain tacky. The waitstaff is very friendly but not attentive what so ever. Finally after getting someone's attention to refill our water, I took that opportunity to ask for more dumpling dipping sauce and the woman just walked away after I said it. No "ok" or nothing. Rude... The service was also kind of slow too. Two customers complained that their food was taking too long while I was there. I was the third person who asked about my food... Also there were flies flying around while I was eating... I don't like having to swat flies away from my food while I eat. 

The food was good though. Kinda worth the wait. The Shanghai dumplings are made fresh and pretty big. The filling and soup is alright. Too much MSG... The combination fried rice was good though. We also got spicy chive and pork dumplings too and those were delicious!! The food was reasonably priced. Dumplings were $5.75 for each 10 pc order. Fried rice was $8.75 I believe. 

Umm. As for this place I'm not too sure I'd return only because the service was too great. Not worth me driving across the bridge and be stuck in traffic for is all.
author: Melysa T.

description:
yum yum yum. this place is surprisingly pretty legit. I would definitely come back if I'm craving xiao loong bao. 

I came in here with no expectations since most places rarely make good dumplings - I'm also half Shanghainese so I didn't want to bring *that* side out of me...  I'd scare people. 

The xio loong bao dumplings were actually pretty soupy and really fresh tasting. My boyfriend loved and devoured the first batch pretty quickly, so we ended up getting two carts so I could get my fill. 

The service was decent - you can't really expect too much from a Chinese restaurant. Also parking was really easy for find. 

If I'm bold enough, I might try other stuff the next time I come back... god forbid!
author: Lucia C.

description:
One order of Dumplings turn into two orders for my boo and I. Soo goood!
Egg Foo Young is surprisingly prepared different but it soo darn tasty and crispy.
They get super packed but its worth the wait!
author: Lynn T.

description:
I like the new location way much better than the original location ( Balboa). Not just the new location is bigger but also clearer. Parking wise, I think both locations are hard to find a parking and depend on the time and day too. 

Food : 
The shanghai dumplings and the spicy wonton taste exactly the same as the original location. The lion head soup, the size of the meat balls seems smaller and taste so so. NEW ITEM : chicken wings extremely disappointed. The wings meats were extremely salty and the sauce tasted like sweet and sour pork chop sauce. The only different I tasted was, they added more balsamic vinegar and a hint of spicy. 

Overall, I love the new location and the food were good. But maybe they should consider improving the chicken wing recipes or take the chicken wings out from the menu.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I really, really want to give them 5 stars because I LOVE their xiao long bao, but I think last time they messed up our order.

We ordered the spicy won tons and from looking through the pictures from the old restaurant I think we received spicy pork and chive dumplings. Not a big deal, but I think I like the sauce and skin of the won ton dish more. 

I still love, love, love the soup dumplings and it's great that they opened this new location because now I am even closer to dumplings!
author: Annaliese D.

description: This restaurant is incompetent and just out right garbage. Wonton soup is horrendous and the dumplings are soggy.  I felt like I was eating water saturated dough.
author: Ada A.

description: Tried this place out for their shanghai dumplings. I shared two dishes with a friend of mine, the shanghai dumplings and the spicy chives and pork dumpling. Each dish came with 10 dumplings for $5.50 each. Not bad of a price especially for my super bad craving of shanghai dumplings. The shanghai dumpling had soup, and it didn't pop when you picked it up compared to other places which is a plus. Some of the dumpling were more of a sticky consistency where the skin isn't as soft but overall it's alright. For the price, can't really go wrong. As for the spicy chives and pork dumpling, it's okay. Not too spicy and the hot sauce is mixed with oil. They add sesame seeds on top to give it more flavor. This was also okay. Can't say much about the other food since I haven't tried it but I'd be back for a shanghai dumpling fix only.
author: Julian Y.

description: The food is decent enough, but the store could be cleaner. They also do not take credit card unless you meet a minimum charge of $20.  Additionally, the service from the waiters is lackluster. The worst part for me though is that the waiters consistently give the wrong change (I tested them twice) and pretend they do not know. Such dishonest business practice is not to be tolerated.
author: Sam K.

description: Why doesn't this place have more 5 star reviews? This place is the bomb. Every dish I've ordered here has been amazing. Loved the dumplings, the garlic pea shoots are amazing, the Chicken and vegetables, braised tofu and mushrooms are all delicious. Haven't ordered a bad dish. Hands down best chinese food I've had in the city!
author: Sydney G.

description: Food was alright. Nothing mind-blowing. The "fried calamari" was not what I expected.
author: Precious Athena P.

description:
I called to ask how long wait is at 7:40pm on Saturday 4/27.  The guy who answered said, "I don't know.  Too many people.  Thanks."  Then hung up on me.  Really?!  
So we still go and about 15 minutes later encountered a wait of maybe 5 minutes.  Timing is everything?  We ordered a bunch of food for just the 2 of us: green beans with eggs (good), green beans with garlic (very good), 2 kinds of dumplings (alright), fried rice (alright but there were lumps of white not mixed in with rest of soy sauce), general tso's chicken (meh), and sweet buns (very good with condensed milk).  Portions are rather generous so we ended up with lots of leftovers.  I would return but you won't find me waiting for a long time with a crowd of "too many people."  Since they do takeout, I'd rather just order and go if that's the case.
author: Elsie N.

description:
Today I went to this place for lunch around 12 noon with a friend.
I came for XlLB or Pen Fried Pork bun.  I remembered last summer I had good Pen Fried PB here,  so I ordered it, and also explored my new dish of lion head pot 砂鍋獅子煲 here, also one fried rice.

I couldn't believe that the Pen Fried PB was not fried enough, still looked very pale.
Worse than that was the skin was soooooooo watery, and too soft. The meat inside was so unmeaty ( very few percent of real meat inside,  yes-"fat chunk").     Pen Fried Pork Bun has not pork inside!?  ARE YOU Kidding????        Customers come here to eat Fried Bun with almost NO meat inside, not fried enough, the skin is watery???    Everything was wrong on Pen Fried Pork Bun.  That was not what I remember as good food of last summer.     

Just less than one year the food quality went down SOOOO much.   The Lion head dish was not worth $11 at all.   Three weeks ago I was eating in my friend house. She treated me her homemade fried dumpling, fried pork bun, and her homemade Lion head. Those are way better than today's dish  here.  So disappointed with $30 spent this lunch.  I totally agree with CL review " this place is for people who did not know what Shanghai food is."  

I am glad I came here today, so I can save my money in next few weeks in CCSF class. and drop of my desire of XLB \  fried Bun from here.   Will NOT come back here any more.    

I am going to bother my 70 years old lady friend for her real Shanghai wonton, dumpling, and bun.   How many restaurants are really worth to try ?
Should we wash our hands and start to learn how to cook meal ourselves?
author: Grace C.

description: Friendly staff, delicious food and accessible for big groups :D
author: Bri U.

description: Shanghai Dumplings and Pan fried dumplings are my fave, bf likes the shanghai noodles too. They are delicious. I didn't care for the chicken wings like everyone else talks about. San Tung is still the best for that. I wouldn't come here to eat the Chinese food on the menu just the specialty stuff I can't get in my hood. I wish they had white vinegar, they only have their special vinegar that they don't give enough of. Good for a dumpling fix for sure!
author: Gessa C.

description: Don't go for the atmosphere. Best dumplings in town, staff is attentive, like the place a lot.
author: Dan S.

description: This place definitely can get packed. Do not order their chow mein. Their noodles are extremely bland with a weird flavor that has no substance to it. Their pot stickers are extremely greasy and so is the rest of their food. We also ordered there xlb and that was decent. The only thing that is really good here is their cucumber salad. It was a good shot for trying out a new dumpling place but I definitely would not come back.
author: Marlene T.

description:
amazing flavors and textures!

highlight was the Pan Fried Chives & Meat Pastries and the Spicy Wontons
author: Mike L.

description:
I took my whole family and my mother to go to this restaurant for the first time. My mom loves Shanghai cuisine and wanted to give this restaurant a try.

The waitress came over and we made small talks with her. Two sentences later, we realized none of the people working there came from Shanghai. My husband expressed we were looking for an authentic Shanghai restaurant. The waitress named Cindy responded by saying they had been in business for more than 10 years. She then walked away suddenly and told us she is too busy to talk to us at all if we weren't ordering. We couldn't say anything because she simply left our table.  A few minutes later she came back but left us again without saying a thing this time. Finally she came back and I told her what I and my daughter would like to order immediately lest she leaves again. My mom told her what she wanted to order but Cindy asked her to be quiet because she could only take order from one person -that's me.  We found that to be very strange and rude but didn't say anything. My mom did order for herself...and asked Cindy if they have delivery service. Cindy asked her not to ask other questions as she is too busy writing the order.  She became increasingly rude, and never responded my mom with an answer.

Since we hadn't been there before, after we ordered a bunch of dishes, my last question to Cindy was if we had ordered enough. She responded there was no way to tell.  Our family dine out a lot and has never encountered wait staff unable to answer this question if they purport to be in business for a long time.

Our dishes came and everything tasted the same, and everything had added sugar so the food were all too sweet. Nothing tasted good or authentic. We asked the manager/owner to come over as we planned to talk to him about our experience. He signaled us to wait, but he never came over for the next 50 minutes we were there. We told another waiter our experience. Then Cindy came back again. This time she was extremely polite to my mom and was so fake that she made my mom uncomfortable. She told me the restaurant caters to white people because they have no idea what's authentic or good. At the minimum she had a response to our question before we ordered. 

Maybe that's why she felt that she didn't have to be respectful to elders such as my mom. She knew we weren't going to return and thus didn't care.  But this is no way to operate a reputable business in a competitive and culturally diverse market.
author: Amanfly p.

description: Great dumplings, dirt cheap prices and zero atmosphere. Few places to sit, but they do take out. Their soup dumplings totally rock!
author: Will G.

description:
The service was great here. I'm a novice in the world of dumplings, but I have a hard time believing anyone could make an argument against this place. 

The meatballs are crazy good. All of the dumplings were cooked perfectly and I haven't regretted an order yet. Can't wait to try the Richmond location.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Shanghai dumplings were very good! Spicy wontons were also tasty. Would come back to try their spicy wings..
author: Emily N.

description: Meh... I was really looking forward to the XLB here because I've heard so many great things from everyone. But, tonight was kinda disappointing. The XLB was not really flavorful and lacked the umami that you'd expect from such a prized dumpling restaurant. My boyfriend and I also got the spicy wonton dumplings, and it was really mushy and the peanut butter based sauce was very overpowering, in our opinion. I was super hungry when I sat down, but just couldn't eat that much because the food wasn't really good... I wish I could like this place, but I'd rather go to Kingdom of Dumpling to satisfy the next XLB craving.
author: Christine S.

description:
I went with my friend and her family who are Chinese so I don't know the names of the dishes we ate (they ordered everything), but most of them were delicious!
- Xiao Long Bao was pretty good
- there was also a delicious vege dish - it was a dark green vege that looked like a bokchoy / spinach hybrid...yum!
- I also really enjoyed the dessert - the outside is a mochi like consistency and the inside is a black bean syrup type thing, def my favorite Chinese dessert :)
author: Kristine B.

description:
I like both of the Shanghai Dumpling King restaurants. This one, however, is bigger than the Richmond District location and is packed to the brim!

Definite must haves:

-dumplings (as that's what they're known for)
-pastry puff for dessert. Amazingly good and comes to you fresh and piping hot.
-Spicy wings

I would definitely pass on the:
-green onion pancakes (weird consistency and I've definitely had better at other places)
-noodles (we ordered the Shanghai style noodles and they were kind of tasteless and mushy)

Prices are pretty reasonable.
author: Jen F.

description: Their dumplings and Shanghai dishes are authentic and delicious. My husband and I enjoy the steamed Shanghai dumplings, chicken fried rice, pea sprouts with garlic sauce, sugar egg puff and the red bean paste cake. And the price is reasonable. They also prepare the dishes quite timely.
author: June F.

description: My family and I love this place. Cheap and fast service. One of the best Shanghai Dumplings  we've ever had. Also love the garlic eggplant, pea shoots, spicy chive dumplings, honey beef, egg puffs, pork steamed buns, and veggie potstickers. This place is under-rated.
author: Jack N.

description:
I tried many dumping places in SF, Shanghai Dumpling King is not the best one. This restaurant need to improve their food.

Crab and pork dumplings -- meat taste not too fresh, the XLB size too big, not juicy at all.

Chicken wings -- too much vinegar in their sauce, the wings had too heavy frozen after taste. 

Location is no good, hard to find parking.

I am looking for their improvement.
author: SteveMorris M.

description:
This place is great -- so lucky to have it close by for a spell! We hope this is a permanent extension, once they move back to the old location (being remodeled right now), that they keep this one running. But many reviews say that this is the same staff here that was over there, so we are enjoying it while we have it.

We had:

The stir fried / sauteed Green Beans: cooked perfectly, firm wrinkly exterior with tender inside. The garlic, onions, and salt all come together to compliment it.  

The Shanghai Dumplings: heaven in your mouth. The broth inside the dumplings are so flavorful.

The Pork Buns: tasty, but on the doughy side. So sweet, almost like dessert.
author: Ches W.

description: I used to really like this place, but had a horrible experience there this weekend. The spicy wontons were disgusting. 3 of them had no meat, just wonton wrappers inside the wonton wrapper. They were just balls of dough. The rest were about 75% balls of dough with 25% meat. The XLB's had all leaked so they were dry and juiceless. The pan fried pork buns were good, but didn't have much meat either. The dan dan noodles was the only really good thing we ate that evening. Sad that they have gone down hill like this.
author: beverly l.

description: Delicious Dumplings. Super cheap. Great lunch specials too
author: Gary B.

description: Went here for lunch with friends and all of us were blown away with the Shanghai steamed dumplings - amazing! Better than Din Tai Fung, and at $6.95 for 10, can't beat that price! The other unexpected favorite? Sweet and sour pork which was crispy and just utterly delicious! Even though we live on the peninsula, think we'll have to trek here every so often.
author: Donna J.

description:
Food was just ok. 
Found a couple of worms in our veggies.
Rice noodle dish got harder as we ate it.
Too salty for my friend and i.
Only thing i liked was the Shanghai dumplings.

Mostly will not go back. 
SOrry!
author: Doris L.

description:
Wow!  My last meal at SDK was so disappointing.   The service was not good at all.   Waitress was rude and waiters would rather not be bothered with customers.  

The service could have been forgiven if the food was up to par but even that has slipped since they opened.  

The XLB's looked overcooked, many of them had split open and loss all of their soup.   The ones that were in-tact had a sweet sugary taste to the soup.   The ginger they give you are pathetic little bits as it it was the leftover ginger that was on the chopping board, and they give you just enough watered down vinegar to coat the bottom of the dish.  

We ordered the lion's head meatballs with gravy and they brought us the soup.  When we told them, they would not bring us the correct dish, but asked us if we wanted to order the one with gravy.  

We also had the shanghai noodles, and as other yelpers have mentioned, it was on the bland, mushy, and boring side.  

The egg puff was super greasy and tasted like the dough was undercooked.
author: Fun T.

description:
I came in on a Sunday night to enjoy a quick dinner with my fiance. I thought it would bee more crowded, but there was plenty of seating at the 6 o'clock hour. We did have to wait a couple minutes beefore we were seated. Some of their business has flocked across the street to Rice Valley. 

I've beeen here many times before, and they are very consistent with their food. Whether it is their red beean pancakes or their famous Shanghai dumplings, the food is always served fresh. There is a good variety of smaller-portion soups (serves 2-3), but I would have to bee in the mood to order it. The dumplings are almost always a safe bet also.

Their vegetable dishes are often times a bit too salty and greasy for my taste, but they are indeed a guilty pleasure. The portions are a little bit on the smaller side, but that is too bee expected with the cost of each dish. Overall, it is good value.

As for dessert, they are also known for their made-to-order sugared egg puffs. Word of caution: definitely let it cool down beefore you bite into it; it's hot! The other fried desserts are also worth a try.

Oh, and we found a bee in our garlic snow peas.
author: Kingsley K.

description: Made both of my favorite dishes - walnut shrimp and black bean sauce over broccoli chicken - perfectly. Also great pot stickers and service. Complimentary green tea.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Very average. 

I seem to find something I dislike in each dish. Granted, the xiao long baos are delicious but after a few too many, the oil/greasiness adds up and leaves me feeling uneasy and gross. Their pseudo San Tung chicken wings has the flavor but not the crunch of the skin. Spicy beans: too salty. Fried pork buns: too doughy/soggy. Veggie Pot with corned beef: too salty/greasy. There's more but main point: many things are overly greasy/doughy/salty but would make an adequate meal for the hungry nearby. Has the general, stereotypical Chinese taste. Executed mediocrely

Glad that it opened in this area though
author: Melanie W.

description: This place is absolutely fantastic.  It's the best dumplings in SF and the Peninsula.  The location is great too as it's not nearly as insane as the spot in the Richmond.  All the dumplings are delicious.  My family and I love to come here.
author: Robert W.

description: Yum yum yum! Granted this restaurant is barely a block from my new place, yet everyone passing through should stop by and taste the delectable dumplings. I tend to be a classicist, ordering pan fried pork dumplings everywhere I go. Shanghai Dumpling King gave my stubborn palate the chance to broaden my horizon with crab dumplings, spicy dumplings and chives aplenty. The space is darling, they deliver and I may get fat off of dumplings alone in the next few months. No regrets.
author: Nadine R.

description: I've only had takeout, but I've done so on multiple occasions. We usually order the Hong Kong dim sum plate and the Shanghai dim sum plate. Then we supplement with soup. I'm not sure about people who say the food is bland. That has not been my experience. I would like to try the more exotic items, but eel doesn't travel well. I've been inside and would say that the place isn't much to look at, but I'm paying for food not decor. And, the food is inexpensive.
author: Therese M.

description:
Shanghai Dumping King is my go to restaurant for XLB in the bay area, I use to frequent the Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa (I believe it is the same owner/operator) but that location is much smaller and normally has a few groups waiting for tables outside.

This location has more seating, same quality of food, and same great prices. For under $30 my girlfriend and I can order enough food for 2 meals. Almost everything I have tried here is great, the staff is attentive and friendly, and parking can normally be found nearby.

My only complaint is that the restaurant is cold and when the door are opened the tables in front of the door can get a strong breeze. Try to sit away from the door and to the side.

On to the food...

The thing everyone goes for is the XLB, steamed pork dumplings with a chicken/pork broth inside which is full of flavor. A good XLB needs to have a good wrapper/skin, it needs to be thick enough to hold the broth and not ripped when picked up; but it also needs to be thin enough to not be overly chewy. The flavor is obviously the most important and these are well seasoned, so not overly salted but enough to bring out the flavor of the filling and broth.

My second go to item is the Lions Head Meatball (not int he soup). These are three massive meatballs serve on top of spinach with a sauce, which If i had to guest would say it is a oyster sauce base. The meatballs are delicious with the sauce, and the spinach is great for mopping up the remaining sauce.

I normally also get their warm sweetened soy milk, mainly because the restaurant is pretty cold. Maybe the owner likes it cold to encourage people to order more dumplings.

I know there will always be people that will say Din Tai Fung is better, and i agree, DTF is a very well known franchise from Taiwan which is famous for their XLB, with locations in LA and rumored to be opening a location in the Bay Area. BUT, DTF will never be as well priced and it is normal to wait 1-2hrs for a table
author: James C.

description: The waitress was killing flies with an electric fly swatter while we ate.  Hearing flies blow up next to the table sure is appetizing.
author: Eric W.

description:
Shanghai dumpling is my favorite.
Spicy wanton, green beans and Chinese Spinach are always good!  I also think the spicy minced pork with vermicelli noodles is a good go to on the menu.  Great food for a great price and the staff is always friendly and smiling!...
author: Elsa K.

description: I have never had a bad meal at this place. Every dumpling I've had here is fantastic. XLB, pork dumplings in soup, spicy chive and pork, pork and crab, meat and veg potstickers. All super delicious. I always order the stir fried rice cakes. Love all the veg options like braised string beans and the bok choy. Also a fan of the egg foo yung. And I can't forget the egg puffs for dessert. Love this place and love that we can bring a group here and get great service.
author: Annette C.

description: I stumbled upon the restaurant after realizing that I hadn't eaten in awhile. I was pretty much starving so ordered the usual flair of dishes fitted for a family of four to have.
